column3: 1)	" Yes
column4: I certainly do. (LAUGHTER)  But let me just first
column5: Cheryl
column6: if you will
column7: I want to thank Charlie for moderating. I want to thank Washington University for hosting us here this evening.  Mr. President
column8: it's good to be with you again this evening
column9: sir.  Cheryl
column10: the president didn't find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq
column11: so he's really turned his campaign into a weapon of mass deception. And the result is that you've been bombarded with advertisements suggesting that I've changed a position on this or that or the other.  Now
column12: the three things they try to say I've changed position on are the Patriot Act; I haven't. I support it. I just don't like the way John Ashcroft has applied it
column13: and we're going to change a few things. The chairman of the Republican Party thinks we ought to change a few things.  No Child Left Behind Act
column14: I voted for it. I support it. I support the goals.  But the president has underfunded it by $28 billion.  Right here in St. Louis
column15: you've laid off 350 teachers. You're 150 -- excuse me
column16: I think it's a little more
column17: about $100 million shy of what you ought to be under the No Child Left Behind Act to help your education system here.  So I complain about that. I've argued that we should fully funded it. The president says I've changed my mind. I haven't changed my mind: I'm going to fully fund it.  So these are the differences.  Now
column18: the president has presided over an economy where we've lost 1.6 million jobs. The first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  I have a plan to put people back to work. That's not wishy- washy.  I'm going to close the loopholes that actually encourage companies to go overseas. The president wants to keep them open. I think I'm right. I think he's wrong.  I'm going to give you a tax cut. The president gave the top 1 percent of income-earners in America
column19: got $89 billion last year
column20: more than the 80 percent of people who earn $100
column21: 000 or less all put together. I think that's wrong. That's not wishy-washy
column22: and that's what I'm fighting for
column23: you.

column3: and thank our panelists. And
column4: Senator
column5: thank you.  I can -- and thanks
column6: Washington U. as well.  I can see why people at your workplace think he changes positions a lot
column7: because he does. He said he voted for the $87 billion
column8: and voted against it right before he voted for it. And that sends a confusing signal to people.  He said he thought Saddam Hussein was a grave threat
column9: and now he said it was a mistake to remove Saddam Hussein from power.  No
column10: I can see why people think that he changes position quite often
column11: because he does.  You know
column12: for a while he was a strong supporter of getting rid of Saddam Hussein. He saw the wisdom -- until the Democrat primary came along and Howard Dean
column13: the anti-war candidate
column14: began to gain on him
column15: and he changed positions.  I don't see how you can lead this country in a time of war
column16: in a time of uncertainty
column17: if you change your mind because of politics.  He just brought up the tax cut. You remember we increased that child credit by $1
column19: reduced the marriage penalty
column20: created a 10 percent tax bracket for the lower-income Americans. That's right at the middle class.  He voted against it. And yet he tells you he's for a middle- class tax cut. It's -- you've got to be consistent when you're the president. There's a lot of pressures. And you've got to be firm and consistent.

column18: the president has presided over an economy where we've lost 1.6 million jobs. The first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  I have a plan to put people back to work. That's not wishy- washy.  I'm going to close the loopholes that actually encourage companies to go overseas. The president wants to keep them open. I think I'm right. I think he's wrong.  I'm going to give you a tax cut. The president gave the top 1 percent of income-earners in America

column3: 1)	" Yes
column4: I certainly do. (LAUGHTER)  But let me just first
column5: Cheryl
column6: if you will
column7: I want to thank Charlie for moderating. I want to thank Washington University for hosting us here this evening.  Mr. President
column8: it's good to be with you again this evening
column9: sir.  Cheryl
column10: the president didn't find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq
column11: so he's really turned his campaign into a weapon of mass deception. And the result is that you've been bombarded with advertisements suggesting that I've changed a position on this or that or the other.  Now
column12: the three things they try to say I've changed position on are the Patriot Act; I haven't. I support it. I just don't like the way John Ashcroft has applied it
column13: and we're going to change a few things. The chairman of the Republican Party thinks we ought to change a few things.  No Child Left Behind Act
column14: I voted for it. I support it. I support the goals.  But the president has underfunded it by $28 billion.  Right here in St. Louis
column15: you've laid off 350 teachers. You're 150 -- excuse me
column16: I think it's a little more
column17: about $100 million shy of what you ought to be under the No Child Left Behind Act to help your education system here.  So I complain about that. I've argued that we should fully funded it. The president says I've changed my mind. I haven't changed my mind: I'm going to fully fund it.  So these are the differences.  Now
column18: the president has presided over an economy where we've lost 1.6 million jobs. The first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  I have a plan to put people back to work. That's not wishy- washy.  I'm going to close the loopholes that actually encourage companies to go overseas. The president wants to keep them open. I think I'm right. I think he's wrong.  I'm going to give you a tax cut. The president gave the top 1 percent of income-earners in America
column19: got $89 billion last year
column20: more than the 80 percent of people who earn $100
column21: 000 or less all put together. I think that's wrong. That's not wishy-washy
column22: and that's what I'm fighting for
column23: you.

column3: and thank our panelists. And
column4: Senator
column5: thank you.  I can -- and thanks
column6: Washington U. as well.  I can see why people at your workplace think he changes positions a lot
column7: because he does. He said he voted for the $87 billion
column8: and voted against it right before he voted for it. And that sends a confusing signal to people.  He said he thought Saddam Hussein was a grave threat
column9: and now he said it was a mistake to remove Saddam Hussein from power.  No
column10: I can see why people think that he changes position quite often
column11: because he does.  You know
column12: for a while he was a strong supporter of getting rid of Saddam Hussein. He saw the wisdom -- until the Democrat primary came along and Howard Dean
column13: the anti-war candidate
column14: began to gain on him
column15: and he changed positions.  I don't see how you can lead this country in a time of war
column16: in a time of uncertainty
column17: if you change your mind because of politics.  He just brought up the tax cut. You remember we increased that child credit by $1
column19: reduced the marriage penalty
column20: created a 10 percent tax bracket for the lower-income Americans. That's right at the middle class.  He voted against it. And yet he tells you he's for a middle- class tax cut. It's -- you've got to be consistent when you're the president. There's a lot of pressures. And you've got to be firm and consistent.

column3: 1)	" Yes
column4: I certainly do. (LAUGHTER)  But let me just first
column5: Cheryl
column6: if you will
column7: I want to thank Charlie for moderating. I want to thank Washington University for hosting us here this evening.  Mr. President
column8: it's good to be with you again this evening
column9: sir.  Cheryl
column10: the president didn't find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq
column11: so he's really turned his campaign into a weapon of mass deception. And the result is that you've been bombarded with advertisements suggesting that I've changed a position on this or that or the other.  Now
column12: the three things they try to say I've changed position on are the Patriot Act; I haven't. I support it. I just don't like the way John Ashcroft has applied it
column13: and we're going to change a few things. The chairman of the Republican Party thinks we ought to change a few things.  No Child Left Behind Act
column14: I voted for it. I support it. I support the goals.  But the president has underfunded it by $28 billion.  Right here in St. Louis
column15: you've laid off 350 teachers. You're 150 -- excuse me
column16: I think it's a little more
column17: about $100 million shy of what you ought to be under the No Child Left Behind Act to help your education system here.  So I complain about that. I've argued that we should fully funded it. The president says I've changed my mind. I haven't changed my mind: I'm going to fully fund it.  So these are the differences.  Now
column18: the president has presided over an economy where we've lost 1.6 million jobs. The first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  I have a plan to put people back to work. That's not wishy- washy.  I'm going to close the loopholes that actually encourage companies to go overseas. The president wants to keep them open. I think I'm right. I think he's wrong.  I'm going to give you a tax cut. The president gave the top 1 percent of income-earners in America
column19: got $89 billion last year
column20: more than the 80 percent of people who earn $100
column21: 000 or less all put together. I think that's wrong. That's not wishy-washy
column22: and that's what I'm fighting for
column23: you.

column3: and thank our panelists. And
column4: Senator
column5: thank you.  I can -- and thanks
column6: Washington U. as well.  I can see why people at your workplace think he changes positions a lot
column7: because he does. He said he voted for the $87 billion
column8: and voted against it right before he voted for it. And that sends a confusing signal to people.  He said he thought Saddam Hussein was a grave threat
column9: and now he said it was a mistake to remove Saddam Hussein from power.  No
column10: I can see why people think that he changes position quite often
column11: because he does.  You know
column12: for a while he was a strong supporter of getting rid of Saddam Hussein. He saw the wisdom -- until the Democrat primary came along and Howard Dean
column13: the anti-war candidate
column14: began to gain on him
column15: and he changed positions.  I don't see how you can lead this country in a time of war
column16: in a time of uncertainty
column17: if you change your mind because of politics.  He just brought up the tax cut. You remember we increased that child credit by $1
column19: reduced the marriage penalty
column20: created a 10 percent tax bracket for the lower-income Americans. That's right at the middle class.  He voted against it. And yet he tells you he's for a middle- class tax cut. It's -- you've got to be consistent when you're the president. There's a lot of pressures. And you've got to be firm and consistent.

column4: I certainly do. (LAUGHTER)  But let me just first
column5: Cheryl
column6: if you will
column7: I want to thank Charlie for moderating. I want to thank Washington University for hosting us here this evening.  Mr. President

column9: sir.  Cheryl
column10: the president didn't find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq
column11: so he's really turned his campaign into a weapon of mass deception. And the result is that you've been bombarded with advertisements suggesting that I've changed a position on this or that or the other.  Now
column12: the three things they try to say I've changed position on are the Patriot Act; I haven't. I support it. I just don't like the way John Ashcroft has applied it
column13: and we're going to change a few things. The chairman of the Republican Party thinks we ought to change a few things.  No Child Left Behind Act
column14: I voted for it. I support it. I support the goals.  But the president has underfunded it by $28 billion.  Right here in St. Louis
column15: you've laid off 350 teachers. You're 150 -- excuse me
column16: I think it's a little more
column17: about $100 million shy of what you ought to be under the No Child Left Behind Act to help your education system here.  So I complain about that. I've argued that we should fully funded it. The president says I've changed my mind. I haven't changed my mind: I'm going to fully fund it.  So these are the differences.  Now
column18: the president has presided over an economy where we've lost 1.6 million jobs. The first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  I have a plan to put people back to work. That's not wishy- washy.  I'm going to close the loopholes that actually encourage companies to go overseas. The president wants to keep them open. I think I'm right. I think he's wrong.  I'm going to give you a tax cut. The president gave the top 1 percent of income-earners in America
column19: got $89 billion last year
column20: more than the 80 percent of people who earn $100
column21: 000 or less all put together. I think that's wrong. That's not wishy-washy
column22: and that's what I'm fighting for

column9: and now he said it was a mistake to remove Saddam Hussein from power.  No

column11: because he does.  You know

column19: reduced the marriage penalty

It's -- you've got to be consistent when you're the president. There's a lot of pressures. And you've got to be firm and consistent.

column3: 10)	" Off-road diesel engines -- we have reached an agreement to reduce pollution from off-road diesel engines by 90 percent. I've got a plan to increase the wetlands by 3 million. We've got an aggressive brown field program to refurbish inner-city sore spots to useful pieces of property.  I proposed to the United States Congress a Clear Skies Initiative to reduce sulfur dioxide
column4: nitrogen oxide and mercury by 70 percent.  I have -- was fought for a very strong title in the farm bill for the conservation reserve program to set aside millions of acres of land to help improve wildlife and the habitat.  We proposed and passed a healthy forest bill which was essential to working with -- particularly in Western states -- to make sure that our forests were protected.  What happens in those forests
column5: because of lousy federal policy
column6: is they grow to be -- they are not -- they're not harvested. They're not taken care of. And as a result
column7: they're like tinderboxes.  And over the last summers I've flown over there. And so
column8: this is a reasonable policy to protect old stands of trees and at the same time make sure our forests aren't vulnerable to the forest fires that have destroyed acres after acres in the West.  We've got a good
column9: common-sense policy.  Now
column10: I'm going to tell you what I really think is going to happen over time is technology is going to change the way we live for the good for the environment.  That's why I proposed a hydrogen automobile -- hydrogen-generated automobile. We're spending $1 billion to come up with the technologies to do that.  That's why I'm a big proponent of clean coal technology
column11: to make sure we can use coal but in a clean way.  I guess you'd say I'm a good steward of the land.  The quality of the air's cleaner since I've been the president. Fewer water complaints since I've been the president. More land being restored since I've been the president.  Thank you for your question.

column2: to listen to that -- the president
column3: I don't think
column4: is living in a world of reality with respect to the environment. Now
column5: if you're a Red Sox fan
column6: that's OK. But if you're a president
column7: it's not.  Let me just say to you
column9: don't throw the labels around. Labels don't mean anything.  I supported welfare reform. I led the fight to put 100
column10: 000 cops on the streets of America. I've been for faith-based initiatives helping to intervene in the lives of young children for years. I was -- broke with my party in 1985
column11: one of the first three Democrats to fight for a balanced budget when it was heresy.  Labels don't fit
column12: ladies and gentlemen.  Now
column13: when it comes to the issue of the environment
column14: this is one of the worst administrations in modern history.  The Clear Skies bill that he just talked about
column15: it's one of those Orwellian names you pull out of the sky
column16: slap it onto something
column17: like ""No Child Left Behind"" but you leave millions of children behind. Here they're leaving the skies and the environment behind.  If they just left the Clean Air Act all alone the way it is today
column18: no change
column19: the air would be cleaner than it is if you pass the Clear Skies act. We're going backwards.  In fact
column20: his environmental enforcement chief air-quality person at the EPA resigned in protest over what they're doing to what they are calling the new source performance standards for air quality.  They're going backwards on the definition for wetlands. They're going backwards on the water quality.  They pulled out of the global warming
column21: declared it dead
column22: didn't even accept the science.  I'm going to be a president who believes in science.

column2: had we joined the Kyoto treaty
column3: which I guess he's referring to
column4: it would have cost America a lot of jobs. It's one of these deals where
column5: in order to be popular in the halls of Europe
column6: you sign a treaty. But I thought it would cost a lot -- I think there's a better way to do it.  And I just told you the facts
column7: sir. The quality of the air is cleaner since I've been the president of the United States. And we'll continue to spend money on research and development
column8: because I truly believe that's the way to get from how we live today to being able to live a standard of living that we're accustomed to and being able to protect our environment better
column9: the use of technologies.

column1: The fact is that the Kyoto treaty was flawed. I was in Kyoto
column2: and I was part of that. I know what happened. But this president didn't try to fix it. He just declared it dead
column3: ladies and gentlemen
column4: and we walked away from the work of 160 nations over 10 years. You wonder
column5: Nikki
column6: why it is that people don't like us in some parts of the world. You just say: Hey
column7: we don't agree with you. Goodbye.  The president's done nothing to try to fix it. I will.

column3: 11)	" Jane
column4: there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example. There is a tax loophole right now. If you're a company in St. Louis working
column5: trying to make jobs here
column6: there is actually an incentive for you to go away. You get more money
column7: you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.  I'm going to shut that loophole
column8: and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.  Secondly
column9: we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.  Third
column10: what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.  Now
column11: you didn't hear any plan from the president
column12: because he doesn't have a plan to lower the cost of health care.  Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620
column13: 000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96
column14: 000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.  I have a plan to cover those folks. And it's a plan that lowers cost for everybody
column15: covers all children. And the way I pay for it -- I'm not fiscally irresponsible -- is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend
column16: the one for him and me and Charlie.  I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education
column18: special-needs education. And that's how we're going to be more competitive
column19: by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.  China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.  We've got to create the products of the future. That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.  And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country
column20: and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.  That's how you create jobs and become competitive.

column1: Let me start with how to control the cost of health care: medical liability reform
column3: which he's opposed. Secondly
column4: allow small businesses to pool together so they can share risk and buy insurance at the same discounts big businesses get to do.  Thirdly
column5: spread what's called health savings accounts. It's good for small businesses
column6: good for owners. You own your own account. You can save tax-free. You get a catastrophic plan to help you on it.  This is different from saying
column7: ""OK
column8: let me incent you to go on the government.""  He's talking about his plan to keep jobs here. You know he calls it an outsourcing to keep -- stop outsourcing. Robert Rubin looked at his plan and said it won't work.  The best way to keep jobs here in America is
column9: one
column10: have an energy plan. I proposed one to the Congress two years ago
column11: encourages conservation
column12: encourages technology to explore for environmentally friendly ways for coal -- to use coal and gas. It encourages the use of renewables like ethanol and biodiesel.  It's stuck in the Senate. He and his running-mate didn't show up to vote when they could have got it going in the Senate.  Less regulations if we want jobs here; legal reform if we want jobs here; and we've got to keep taxes low.  Now
column13: he says he's only going to tax the rich. Do you realize
column15: 000 small businesses will be taxed under his plan because most small businesses are Subchapter S corps or limited partnerships
column16: and they pay tax at the individual income tax level.  And so when you're running up the taxes like that
column18: and that's not how you keep jobs here.

column2: Charlie. I've never promised that. I'm not going to
column3: because that would be pandering. You can't. But what you can do is create a fair playing field
column4: and that's what I'm talking about.  But let me just address what the president just said.  Ladies and gentlemen
column5: that's just not true what he said. The Wall Street Journal said 96 percent of small businesses are not affected at all by my plan.  And you know why he gets that count? The president got $84 from a timber company that owns
column6: and he's counted as a small business. Dick Cheney's counted as a small business. That's how they do things. That's just not right.

column1: I own a timber company? (LAUGHTER)  That's news to me.  (LAUGHTER)  Need some wood?  (LAUGHTER)  Most small businesses are Subchapter S corps. They just are.  I met Grant Milliron
column3: Ohio. He's creating jobs. Most small businesses -- 70 percent of the new jobs in America are created by small businesses.  Taxes are going up when you run up the top two brackets. It's a fact.

column3: 11)	" Jane
column4: there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example. There is a tax loophole right now. If you're a company in St. Louis working
column5: trying to make jobs here
column6: there is actually an incentive for you to go away. You get more money
column7: you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.  I'm going to shut that loophole
column8: and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.  Secondly
column9: we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.  Third
column10: what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.  Now
column11: you didn't hear any plan from the president
column12: because he doesn't have a plan to lower the cost of health care.  Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620
column13: 000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96
column14: 000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.  I have a plan to cover those folks. And it's a plan that lowers cost for everybody
column15: covers all children. And the way I pay for it -- I'm not fiscally irresponsible -- is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend
column16: the one for him and me and Charlie.  I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education
column18: special-needs education. And that's how we're going to be more competitive
column19: by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.  China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.  We've got to create the products of the future. That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.  And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country
column20: and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.  That's how you create jobs and become competitive.

column1: Let me start with how to control the cost of health care: medical liability reform
column3: which he's opposed. Secondly
column4: allow small businesses to pool together so they can share risk and buy insurance at the same discounts big businesses get to do.  Thirdly
column5: spread what's called health savings accounts. It's good for small businesses
column6: good for owners. You own your own account. You can save tax-free. You get a catastrophic plan to help you on it.  This is different from saying
column7: ""OK
column8: let me incent you to go on the government.""  He's talking about his plan to keep jobs here. You know he calls it an outsourcing to keep -- stop outsourcing. Robert Rubin looked at his plan and said it won't work.  The best way to keep jobs here in America is
column9: one
column10: have an energy plan. I proposed one to the Congress two years ago
column11: encourages conservation
column12: encourages technology to explore for environmentally friendly ways for coal -- to use coal and gas. It encourages the use of renewables like ethanol and biodiesel.  It's stuck in the Senate. He and his running-mate didn't show up to vote when they could have got it going in the Senate.  Less regulations if we want jobs here; legal reform if we want jobs here; and we've got to keep taxes low.  Now
column13: he says he's only going to tax the rich. Do you realize
column15: 000 small businesses will be taxed under his plan because most small businesses are Subchapter S corps or limited partnerships
column16: and they pay tax at the individual income tax level.  And so when you're running up the taxes like that
column18: and that's not how you keep jobs here.

column2: Charlie. I've never promised that. I'm not going to
column3: because that would be pandering. You can't. But what you can do is create a fair playing field
column4: and that's what I'm talking about.  But let me just address what the president just said.  Ladies and gentlemen
column5: that's just not true what he said. The Wall Street Journal said 96 percent of small businesses are not affected at all by my plan.  And you know why he gets that count? The president got $84 from a timber company that owns
column6: and he's counted as a small business. Dick Cheney's counted as a small business. That's how they do things. That's just not right.

column1: I own a timber company? (LAUGHTER)  That's news to me.  (LAUGHTER)  Need some wood?  (LAUGHTER)  Most small businesses are Subchapter S corps. They just are.  I met Grant Milliron
column3: Ohio. He's creating jobs. Most small businesses -- 70 percent of the new jobs in America are created by small businesses.  Taxes are going up when you run up the top two brackets. It's a fact.

column3: 11)	" Jane
column4: there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example. There is a tax loophole right now. If you're a company in St. Louis working
column5: trying to make jobs here
column6: there is actually an incentive for you to go away. You get more money
column7: you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.  I'm going to shut that loophole
column8: and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.  Secondly
column9: we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.  Third
column10: what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.  Now
column11: you didn't hear any plan from the president
column12: because he doesn't have a plan to lower the cost of health care.  Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620
column13: 000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96
column14: 000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.  I have a plan to cover those folks. And it's a plan that lowers cost for everybody
column15: covers all children. And the way I pay for it -- I'm not fiscally irresponsible -- is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend
column16: the one for him and me and Charlie.  I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education
column18: special-needs education. And that's how we're going to be more competitive
column19: by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.  China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.  We've got to create the products of the future. That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.  And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country
column20: and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.  That's how you create jobs and become competitive.

column1: Let me start with how to control the cost of health care: medical liability reform
column3: which he's opposed. Secondly
column4: allow small businesses to pool together so they can share risk and buy insurance at the same discounts big businesses get to do.  Thirdly
column5: spread what's called health savings accounts. It's good for small businesses
column6: good for owners. You own your own account. You can save tax-free. You get a catastrophic plan to help you on it.  This is different from saying
column7: ""OK
column8: let me incent you to go on the government.""  He's talking about his plan to keep jobs here. You know he calls it an outsourcing to keep -- stop outsourcing. Robert Rubin looked at his plan and said it won't work.  The best way to keep jobs here in America is
column9: one
column10: have an energy plan. I proposed one to the Congress two years ago
column11: encourages conservation
column12: encourages technology to explore for environmentally friendly ways for coal -- to use coal and gas. It encourages the use of renewables like ethanol and biodiesel.  It's stuck in the Senate. He and his running-mate didn't show up to vote when they could have got it going in the Senate.  Less regulations if we want jobs here; legal reform if we want jobs here; and we've got to keep taxes low.  Now
column13: he says he's only going to tax the rich. Do you realize
column15: 000 small businesses will be taxed under his plan because most small businesses are Subchapter S corps or limited partnerships
column16: and they pay tax at the individual income tax level.  And so when you're running up the taxes like that
column18: and that's not how you keep jobs here.

column2: Charlie. I've never promised that. I'm not going to
column3: because that would be pandering. You can't. But what you can do is create a fair playing field
column4: and that's what I'm talking about.  But let me just address what the president just said.  Ladies and gentlemen
column5: that's just not true what he said. The Wall Street Journal said 96 percent of small businesses are not affected at all by my plan.  And you know why he gets that count? The president got $84 from a timber company that owns
column6: and he's counted as a small business. Dick Cheney's counted as a small business. That's how they do things. That's just not right.

column1: I own a timber company? (LAUGHTER)  That's news to me.  (LAUGHTER)  Need some wood?  (LAUGHTER)  Most small businesses are Subchapter S corps. They just are.  I met Grant Milliron
column3: Ohio. He's creating jobs. Most small businesses -- 70 percent of the new jobs in America are created by small businesses.  Taxes are going up when you run up the top two brackets. It's a fact.

column4: there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example. There is a tax loophole right now. If you're a company in St. Louis working

column8: and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.  Secondly
column9: we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.  Third
column10: what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.  Now
column11: you didn't hear any plan from the president
column12: because he doesn't have a plan to lower the cost of health care.  Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620
column13: 000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96
column14: 000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.  I have a plan to cover those folks. And it's a plan that lowers cost for everybody
column15: covers all children. And the way I pay for it -- I'm not fiscally irresponsible -- is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend
column16: the one for him and me and Charlie.  I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education
column18: special-needs education. And that's how we're going to be more competitive
column19: by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.  China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.  We've got to create the products of the future. That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.  And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country
column20: and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.  That's how you create jobs and become competitive.

column4: there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example. There is a tax loophole right now. If you're a company in St. Louis working
column5: trying to make jobs here

column7: you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.  I'm going to shut that loophole
column8: and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.  Secondly
column9: we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.  Third
column10: what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.  Now

column16: the one for him and me and Charlie.  I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education
column18: special-needs education. And that's how we're going to be more competitive
column19: by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.  China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.  We've got to create the products of the future. That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.  And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country
column20: and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.  That's how you create jobs and become competitive.

column3: 11)	" Jane
column4: there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example. There is a tax loophole right now. If you're a company in St. Louis working
column5: trying to make jobs here
column6: there is actually an incentive for you to go away. You get more money
column7: you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.  I'm going to shut that loophole
column8: and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.  Secondly
column9: we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.  Third
column10: what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.  Now
column11: you didn't hear any plan from the president
column12: because he doesn't have a plan to lower the cost of health care.  Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620
column13: 000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96
column14: 000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.  I have a plan to cover those folks. And it's a plan that lowers cost for everybody
column15: covers all children. And the way I pay for it -- I'm not fiscally irresponsible -- is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend
column16: the one for him and me and Charlie.  I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education
column18: special-needs education. And that's how we're going to be more competitive
column19: by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.  China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.  We've got to create the products of the future. That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.  And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country
column20: and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.  That's how you create jobs and become competitive.

column3: 12)	" I appreciate that. I really don't think your rights are being watered down. As a matter of fact
column4: I wouldn't support it if I thought that.  Every action being taken against terrorists requires court order
column5: requires scrutiny.  As a matter of fact
column6: the tools now given to the terrorist fighters are the same tools that we've been using against drug dealers and white-collar criminals.  So I really don't think so. I hope you don't think that. I mean
column7: I -- because I think whoever is the president must guard your liberties
column8: must not erode your rights in America.  The Patriot Act is necessary
column9: for example
column10: because parts of the FBI couldn't talk to each other. The intelligence-gathering and the law-enforcement arms of the FBI just couldn't share intelligence under the old law. And that didn't make any sense.  Our law enforcement must have every tool necessary to find and disrupt terrorists at home and abroad before they hurt us again. That's the task of the 21st century.  And so
column11: I don't think the Patriot Act abridges your rights at all.  And I know it's necessary. I can remember being in upstate New York talking to FBI agents that helped bust a Lackawanna cell up there. And they told me they could not have performed their duty
column12: the duty we all expect of them
column13: if they did not have the ability to communicate with each other under the Patriot Act.

column3: said he thought that the Patriot Act has to be changed and fixed. Congressman Jim Sensenbrenner

column6: the tools now given to the terrorist fighters are the same tools that we've been using against drug dealers and white-collar criminals.  So I really don't think so. I hope you don't think that. I mean
column7: I -- because I think whoever is the president must guard your liberties
column8: must not erode your rights in America.  The Patriot Act is necessary
column9: for example
column10: because parts of the FBI couldn't talk to each other. The intelligence-gathering and the law-enforcement arms of the FBI just couldn't share intelligence under the old law. And that didn't make any sense.  Our law enforcement must have every tool necessary to find and disrupt terrorists at home and abroad before they hurt us again. That's the task of the 21st century. column11: I don't think the Patriot Act abridges your rights at all.  And I know it's necessary. I can remember being in upstate New York talking to FBI agents that helped bust a Lackawanna cell up there. And they told me they could not have performed their duty
column12: the duty we all expect of them
column13: if they did not have the ability to communicate with each other under the Patriot Act.

column3: 14)	" I'm not telling. (LAUGHTER)  I really don't have -- haven't picked anybody yet. Plus
column4: I want them all voting for me.  (LAUGHTER)  I would pick somebody who would not allow their personal opinion to get in the way of the law. I would pick somebody who would strictly interpret the Constitution of the United States.  Let me give you a couple of examples
column5: I guess
column6: of the kind of person I wouldn't pick.  I wouldn't pick a judge who said that the Pledge of Allegiance couldn't be said in a school because it had the words ""under God"" in it. I think that's an example of a judge allowing personal opinion to enter into the decision-making process as opposed to a strict interpretation of the Constitution.  Another example would be the Dred Scott case
column7: which is where judges
column9: said that the Constitution allowed slavery because of personal property rights.  That's a personal opinion. That's not what the Constitution says. The Constitution of the United States says we're all -- you know
column10: it doesn't say that. It doesn't speak to the equality of America.  And so
column11: I would pick people that would be strict constructionists. We've got plenty of lawmakers in Washington
column12: D.C. . Legislators make law; judges interpret the Constitution.  And I suspect one of us will have a pick at the end of next year -- the next four years. And that's the kind of judge I'm going to put on there. No litmus test except for how they interpret the Constitution.  Thank you.

column2: Charlie. A few years ago when he came to office
column3: the president said -- these are his words -- ""What we need are some good conservative judges on the courts.""  And he said also that his two favorite justices are Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas.  So you get a pretty good sense of where he's heading if he were to appoint somebody.  Now
column4: here's what I believe. I don't believe we need a good conservative judge
column5: and I don't believe we need a good liberal judge. I don't believe we need a good judge of that kind of definition on either side.  I subscribe to the Justice Potter Stewart standard. He was a justice on the Supreme Court of the United States. And he said the mark of a good judge
column6: good justice
column7: is that when you're reading their decision
column9: you can't tell if it's written by a man or woman
column10: a liberal or a conservative
column11: a Muslim
column12: a Jew or a Christian. You just know you're reading a good judicial decision.  What I want to find
column13: if I am privileged to have the opportunity to do it -- and the Supreme Court of the United States is at stake in this race
column14: ladies and gentlemen.  The future of things that matter to you -- in terms of civil rights
column15: what kind of Justice Department you'll have
column16: whether we'll enforce the law. Will we have equal opportunity? Will women's rights be protected? Will we have equal pay for women
column17: which is going backwards? Will a woman's right to choose be protected?  These are constitutional rights
column18: and I want to make sure we have judges who interpret the Constitution of the United States according to the law.

column3: 14)	" I'm not telling. (LAUGHTER)  I really don't have -- haven't picked anybody yet. Plus
column4: I want them all voting for me.  (LAUGHTER)  I would pick somebody who would not allow their personal opinion to get in the way of the law. I would pick somebody who would strictly interpret the Constitution of the United States.  Let me give you a couple of examples
column5: I guess
column6: of the kind of person I wouldn't pick.  I wouldn't pick a judge who said that the Pledge of Allegiance couldn't be said in a school because it had the words ""under God"" in it. I think that's an example of a judge allowing personal opinion to enter into the decision-making process as opposed to a strict interpretation of the Constitution.  Another example would be the Dred Scott case
column7: which is where judges
column9: said that the Constitution allowed slavery because of personal property rights.  That's a personal opinion. That's not what the Constitution says. The Constitution of the United States says we're all -- you know
column10: it doesn't say that. It doesn't speak to the equality of America.  And so
column11: I would pick people that would be strict constructionists. We've got plenty of lawmakers in Washington
column12: D.C. . Legislators make law; judges interpret the Constitution.  And I suspect one of us will have a pick at the end of next year -- the next four years. And that's the kind of judge I'm going to put on there. No litmus test except for how they interpret the Constitution.  Thank you.

column2: Charlie. A few years ago when he came to office
column3: the president said -- these are his words -- ""What we need are some good conservative judges on the courts.""  And he said also that his two favorite justices are Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas.  So you get a pretty good sense of where he's heading if he were to appoint somebody.  Now
column4: here's what I believe. I don't believe we need a good conservative judge
column5: and I don't believe we need a good liberal judge. I don't believe we need a good judge of that kind of definition on either side.  I subscribe to the Justice Potter Stewart standard. He was a justice on the Supreme Court of the United States. And he said the mark of a good judge
column6: good justice
column7: is that when you're reading their decision
column9: you can't tell if it's written by a man or woman
column10: a liberal or a conservative
column11: a Muslim
column12: a Jew or a Christian. You just know you're reading a good judicial decision.  What I want to find
column13: if I am privileged to have the opportunity to do it -- and the Supreme Court of the United States is at stake in this race
column14: ladies and gentlemen.  The future of things that matter to you -- in terms of civil rights
column15: what kind of Justice Department you'll have
column16: whether we'll enforce the law. Will we have equal opportunity? Will women's rights be protected? Will we have equal pay for women
column17: which is going backwards? Will a woman's right to choose be protected?  These are constitutional rights
column18: and I want to make sure we have judges who interpret the Constitution of the United States according to the law.

column3: 14)	" I'm not telling. (LAUGHTER)  I really don't have -- haven't picked anybody yet. Plus
column4: I want them all voting for me.  (LAUGHTER)  I would pick somebody who would not allow their personal opinion to get in the way of the law. I would pick somebody who would strictly interpret the Constitution of the United States.  Let me give you a couple of examples
column5: I guess
column6: of the kind of person I wouldn't pick.  I wouldn't pick a judge who said that the Pledge of Allegiance couldn't be said in a school because it had the words ""under God"" in it. I think that's an example of a judge allowing personal opinion to enter into the decision-making process as opposed to a strict interpretation of the Constitution.  Another example would be the Dred Scott case
column7: which is where judges
column9: said that the Constitution allowed slavery because of personal property rights.  That's a personal opinion. That's not what the Constitution says. The Constitution of the United States says we're all -- you know
column10: it doesn't say that. It doesn't speak to the equality of America.  And so
column11: I would pick people that would be strict constructionists. We've got plenty of lawmakers in Washington
column12: D.C. . Legislators make law; judges interpret the Constitution.  And I suspect one of us will have a pick at the end of next year -- the next four years. And that's the kind of judge I'm going to put on there. No litmus test except for how they interpret the Constitution.  Thank you.

column2: Charlie. A few years ago when he came to office
column3: the president said -- these are his words -- ""What we need are some good conservative judges on the courts.""  And he said also that his two favorite justices are Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas.  So you get a pretty good sense of where he's heading if he were to appoint somebody.  Now
column4: here's what I believe. I don't believe we need a good conservative judge
column5: and I don't believe we need a good liberal judge. I don't believe we need a good judge of that kind of definition on either side.  I subscribe to the Justice Potter Stewart standard. He was a justice on the Supreme Court of the United States. And he said the mark of a good judge
column6: good justice
column7: is that when you're reading their decision
column9: you can't tell if it's written by a man or woman
column10: a liberal or a conservative
column11: a Muslim
column12: a Jew or a Christian. You just know you're reading a good judicial decision.  What I want to find
column13: if I am privileged to have the opportunity to do it -- and the Supreme Court of the United States is at stake in this race
column14: ladies and gentlemen.  The future of things that matter to you -- in terms of civil rights
column15: what kind of Justice Department you'll have
column16: whether we'll enforce the law. Will we have equal opportunity? Will women's rights be protected? Will we have equal pay for women
column17: which is going backwards? Will a woman's right to choose be protected?  These are constitutional rights
column18: and I want to make sure we have judges who interpret the Constitution of the United States according to the law.

column3: 15)	" I would say to that person exactly what I will say to you right now. First of all
column4: I cannot tell you how deeply I respect the belief about life and when it begins. I'm a Catholic
column5: raised a Catholic. I was an altar boy. Religion has been a huge part of my life. It helped lead me through a war
column6: leads me today.  But I can't take what is an article of faith for me and legislate it for someone who doesn't share that article of faith
column7: whether they be agnostic
column9: Jew
column10: Protestant
column11: whatever. I can't do that.  But I can counsel people. I can talk reasonably about life and about responsibility. I can talk to people
column12: as my wife Teresa does
column13: about making other choices
column14: and about abstinence
column15: and about all these other things that we ought to do as a responsible society.  But as a president
column16: I have to represent all the people in the nation. And I have to make that judgment.  Now
column17: I believe that you can take that position and not be pro- abortion
column18: but you have to afford people their constitutional rights. And that means being smart about allowing people to be fully educated
column19: to know what their options are in life
column20: and making certain that you don't deny a poor person the right to be able to have whatever the constitution affords them if they can't afford it otherwise.  That's why I think it's important. That's why I think it's important for the United States
column21: for instance
column22: not to have this rigid ideological restriction on helping families around the world to be able to make a smart decision about family planning.  You'll help prevent AIDS.  You'll help prevent unwanted children
column23: unwanted pregnancies.  You'll actually do a better job
column24: I think
column25: of passing on the moral responsibility that is expressed in your question. And I truly respect it.

column1: I'm trying to decipher that. My answer is
column2: we're not going to spend taxpayers' money on abortion.  This is an issue that divides America
column3: but certainly reasonable people can agree on how to reduce abortions in America.  I signed the partial-birth -- the ban on partial-birth abortion. It's a brutal practice. It's one way to help reduce abortions. My opponent voted against the ban.  I think there ought to be parental notification laws. He's against them.  I signed a bill called the Unborn Victims of Violence Act.  In other words
column4: if you're a mom and you're pregnant and you get killed
column5: the murderer gets tried for two cases
column6: not just one. My opponent was against that.  These are reasonable ways to help promote a culture of life in America. I think it is a worthy goal in America to have every child protected by law and welcomed in life.  I also think we ought to continue to have good adoption law as an alternative to abortion.  And we need to promote maternity group homes
column7: which my administration has done.  Culture of life is really important for a country to have if it's going to be a hospitable society.  Thank you.

column3: the president just said
column4: categorically
column5: my opponent is against this
column6: my opponent is against that. You know
column7: it's just not that simple. No
column8: I'm not. I'm against the partial-birth abortion
column9: but you've got to have an exception for the life of the mother and the health of the mother under the strictest test of bodily injury to the mother.  Secondly
column10: with respect to parental notification
column11: I'm not going to require a 16-or 17-year-old kid who's been raped by her father and who's pregnant to have to notify her father. So you got to have a judicial intervention. And because they didn't have a judicial intervention where she could go somewhere and get help
column12: I voted against it. It's never quite as simple as the president wants you to believe.

column2: it's pretty simple when they say: Are you for a ban on partial birth abortion? Yes or no? And he was given a chance to vote
column3: and he voted no. And that's just the way it is. That's a vote. It came right up. It's clear for everybody to see. And as I said: You can run but you can't hide the reality.

column6: leads me today.  But I can't take what is an article of faith for me and legislate it for someone who doesn't share that article of faith
column7: whether they be agnostic
column9: Jew
column10: Protestant
column11: whatever. I can't do that.  But I can counsel people. I can talk reasonably about life and about responsibility. I can talk to people
column12: as my wife Teresa does
column13: about making other choices
column14: and about abstinence
column15: and about all these other things that we ought to do as a responsible society.  But as a president
column16: I have to represent all the people in the nation. And I have to make that judgment.  Now
column17: I believe that you can take that position and not be pro- abortion
column18: but you have to afford people their constitutional rights. And that means being smart about allowing people to be fully educated
column19: to know what their options are in life
column20: and making certain that you don't deny a poor person the right to be able to have whatever the constitution affords them if they can't afford it otherwise.  That's why I think it's important. That's why I think it's important for the United States
column21: for instance
column22: not to have this rigid ideological restriction on helping families around the world to be able to make a smart decision about family planning.  You'll help prevent AIDS.  You'll help prevent unwanted children
column23: unwanted pregnancies.  You'll actually do a better job
column24: I think
column25: of passing on the moral responsibility that is expressed in your question. And I truly respect it.

column1: I'm trying to decipher that. My answer is
column2: we're not going to spend taxpayers' money on abortion.  This is an issue that divides America
column3: but certainly reasonable people can agree on how to reduce abortions in America.  I signed the partial-birth -- the ban on partial-birth abortion. It's a brutal practice. It's one way to help reduce abortions. My opponent voted against the ban.  I think there ought to be parental notification laws. He's against them.  I signed a bill called the Unborn Victims of Violence Act.  In other words
column4: if you're a mom and you're pregnant and you get killed
column5: the murderer gets tried for two cases
column6: not just one. My opponent was against that.  These are reasonable ways to help promote a culture of life in America. I think it is a worthy goal in America to have every child protected by law and welcomed in life.  I also think we ought to continue to have good adoption law as an alternative to abortion.  And we need to promote maternity group homes
column7: which my administration has done.  Culture of life is really important for a country to have if it's going to be a hospitable society.  Thank you.

column3: the president just said
column4: categorically
column5: my opponent is against this
column6: my opponent is against that. You know
column7: it's just not that simple. No
column8: I'm not. I'm against the partial-birth abortion
column9: but you've got to have an exception for the life of the mother and the health of the mother under the strictest test of bodily injury to the mother.  Secondly
column10: with respect to parental notification
column11: I'm not going to require a 16-or 17-year-old kid who's been raped by her father and who's pregnant to have to notify her father. So you got to have a judicial intervention. And because they didn't have a judicial intervention where she could go somewhere and get help
column12: I voted against it. It's never quite as simple as the president wants you to believe.

column2: it's pretty simple when they say: Are you for a ban on partial birth abortion? Yes or no? And he was given a chance to vote
column3: and he voted no. And that's just the way it is. That's a vote. It came right up. It's clear for everybody to see. And as I said: You can run but you can't hide the reality.

column1: I have made a lot of decisions
column3: like appointments to boards you never heard of
column4: and some of them big. And in a war
column5: there's a lot of -- there's a lot of tactical decisions that historians will look back and say: He shouldn't have done that. He shouldn't have made that decision. And I'll take responsibility for them. I'm human.  But on the big questions
column6: about whether or not we should have gone into Afghanistan
column7: the big question about whether we should have removed somebody in Iraq
column9: because I think they're right.  That's really what you're -- when they ask about the mistakes
column10: that's what they're talking about. They're trying to say
column11: ""Did you make a mistake going into Iraq?"" And the answer is
column12: ""Absolutely not."" It was the right decision.  The Duelfer report confirmed that decision today
column13: because what Saddam Hussein was doing was trying to get rid of sanctions so he could reconstitute a weapons program. And the biggest threat facing America is terrorists with weapons of mass destruction.  We knew he hated us. We knew he'd been -- invaded other countries. We knew he tortured his own people.  On the tax cut
column14: it's a big decision. I did the right decision. Our recession was one of the shallowest in modern history.  Now
column15: you asked what mistakes. I made some mistakes in appointing people
column16: but I'm not going to name them. I don't want to hurt their feelings on national TV.  (LAUGHTER)

column2: and I'm fully prepared to accept any mistakes that history judges to my administration
column3: because the president makes the decisions
column4: the president has to take the responsibility.

column1: I believe the president made a huge mistake
column3: not to live up to his own standard
column4: which was: build a true global coalition
column5: give the inspectors time to finish their job and go through the U.N. process to its end and go to war as a last resort. I ask each of you just to look into your hearts
column6: look into your guts. Gut-check time. Was this really going to war as a last resort?  The president rushed our nation to war without a plan to win the peace. And simple things weren't done.  That's why Senator Lugar says: incompetent in the delivery of services. That's why Senator Hagel
column7: Republican
column9: you know: beyond pitiful
column10: beyond embarrassing
column11: in the zone of dangerous.  We didn't guard 850
column12: 000 tons of ammo. That ammo is now being used against our kids. Ten thousand out of 12
column13: 000 Humvees aren't armored. I visited some of those kids with no limbs today
column14: because they didn't have the armor on those vehicles. They didn't have the right body armor.  I've met parents who've on the Internet gotten the armor to send their kids.  There is no bigger judgment for a president of the United states than how you take a nation to war. And you can't say
column15: because Saddam might have done it 10 years from now
column16: that's a reason; that's an excuse.

column1: He complains about the fact our troops don't have adequate equipment
column2: yet he voted against the $87 billion supplemental I sent to the Congress and then issued one of the most amazing quotes in political history: ""I actually did vote for the $87 billion before I voted against it."" Saddam Hussein was a risk to our country
column3: ma'am. And he was a risk that -- and this is where we just have a difference of opinion.  The truth of that matter is
column4: if you listen carefully
column5: Saddam would still be in power if he were the president of the United States
column6: ""And the world would be a lot better off.""

column2: but here's what I'll say about the $87 billion. I made a mistake in the way I talk about it. He made a mistake in invading Iraq. Which is a worse decision?  Now
column3: I voted the way I voted because I saw that he had the policy wrong and I wanted accountability. I didn't want to give a slush fund to Halliburton. I also thought the wealthiest people in America ought to pay for it
column4: ladies and gentlemen. He wants your kids to pay for it. I wanted us to pay for it
column5: since we're at war. I don't think that's a bad decision.

column1: I have made a lot of decisions
column3: like appointments to boards you never heard of
column4: and some of them big. And in a war
column5: there's a lot of -- there's a lot of tactical decisions that historians will look back and say: He shouldn't have done that. He shouldn't have made that decision. And I'll take responsibility for them. I'm human.  But on the big questions
column6: about whether or not we should have gone into Afghanistan
column7: the big question about whether we should have removed somebody in Iraq
column9: because I think they're right.  That's really what you're -- when they ask about the mistakes
column10: that's what they're talking about. They're trying to say
column11: ""Did you make a mistake going into Iraq?"" And the answer is
column12: ""Absolutely not."" It was the right decision.  The Duelfer report confirmed that decision today
column13: because what Saddam Hussein was doing was trying to get rid of sanctions so he could reconstitute a weapons program. And the biggest threat facing America is terrorists with weapons of mass destruction.  We knew he hated us. We knew he'd been -- invaded other countries. We knew he tortured his own people.  On the tax cut
column14: it's a big decision. I did the right decision. Our recession was one of the shallowest in modern history.  Now
column15: you asked what mistakes. I made some mistakes in appointing people
column16: but I'm not going to name them. I don't want to hurt their feelings on national TV.  (LAUGHTER)

column2: and I'm fully prepared to accept any mistakes that history judges to my administration
column3: because the president makes the decisions
column4: the president has to take the responsibility.

column1: I believe the president made a huge mistake
column3: not to live up to his own standard
column4: which was: build a true global coalition
column5: give the inspectors time to finish their job and go through the U.N. process to its end and go to war as a last resort. I ask each of you just to look into your hearts
column6: look into your guts. Gut-check time. Was this really going to war as a last resort?  The president rushed our nation to war without a plan to win the peace. And simple things weren't done.  That's why Senator Lugar says: incompetent in the delivery of services. That's why Senator Hagel
column7: Republican
column9: you know: beyond pitiful
column10: beyond embarrassing
column11: in the zone of dangerous.  We didn't guard 850
column12: 000 tons of ammo. That ammo is now being used against our kids. Ten thousand out of 12
column13: 000 Humvees aren't armored. I visited some of those kids with no limbs today
column14: because they didn't have the armor on those vehicles. They didn't have the right body armor.  I've met parents who've on the Internet gotten the armor to send their kids.  There is no bigger judgment for a president of the United states than how you take a nation to war. And you can't say
column15: because Saddam might have done it 10 years from now
column16: that's a reason; that's an excuse.

column1: He complains about the fact our troops don't have adequate equipment
column2: yet he voted against the $87 billion supplemental I sent to the Congress and then issued one of the most amazing quotes in political history: ""I actually did vote for the $87 billion before I voted against it."" Saddam Hussein was a risk to our country
column3: ma'am. And he was a risk that -- and this is where we just have a difference of opinion.  The truth of that matter is
column4: if you listen carefully
column5: Saddam would still be in power if he were the president of the United States
column6: ""And the world would be a lot better off.""

column2: but here's what I'll say about the $87 billion. I made a mistake in the way I talk about it. He made a mistake in invading Iraq. Which is a worse decision?  Now
column3: I voted the way I voted because I saw that he had the policy wrong and I wanted accountability. I didn't want to give a slush fund to Halliburton. I also thought the wealthiest people in America ought to pay for it
column4: ladies and gentlemen. He wants your kids to pay for it. I wanted us to pay for it
column5: since we're at war. I don't think that's a bad decision.

column1: I have made a lot of decisions
column3: like appointments to boards you never heard of
column4: and some of them big. And in a war
column5: there's a lot of -- there's a lot of tactical decisions that historians will look back and say: He shouldn't have done that. He shouldn't have made that decision. And I'll take responsibility for them. I'm human.  But on the big questions
column6: about whether or not we should have gone into Afghanistan
column7: the big question about whether we should have removed somebody in Iraq
column9: because I think they're right.  That's really what you're -- when they ask about the mistakes
column10: that's what they're talking about. They're trying to say
column11: ""Did you make a mistake going into Iraq?"" And the answer is
column12: ""Absolutely not."" It was the right decision.  The Duelfer report confirmed that decision today
column13: because what Saddam Hussein was doing was trying to get rid of sanctions so he could reconstitute a weapons program. And the biggest threat facing America is terrorists with weapons of mass destruction.  We knew he hated us. We knew he'd been -- invaded other countries. We knew he tortured his own people.  On the tax cut
column14: it's a big decision. I did the right decision. Our recession was one of the shallowest in modern history.  Now
column15: you asked what mistakes. I made some mistakes in appointing people
column16: but I'm not going to name them. I don't want to hurt their feelings on national TV.  (LAUGHTER)

column2: and I'm fully prepared to accept any mistakes that history judges to my administration
column3: because the president makes the decisions
column4: the president has to take the responsibility.

column1: I believe the president made a huge mistake
column3: not to live up to his own standard
column4: which was: build a true global coalition
column5: give the inspectors time to finish their job and go through the U.N. process to its end and go to war as a last resort. I ask each of you just to look into your hearts
column6: look into your guts. Gut-check time. Was this really going to war as a last resort?  The president rushed our nation to war without a plan to win the peace. And simple things weren't done.  That's why Senator Lugar says: incompetent in the delivery of services. That's why Senator Hagel
column7: Republican
column9: you know: beyond pitiful
column10: beyond embarrassing
column11: in the zone of dangerous.  We didn't guard 850
column12: 000 tons of ammo. That ammo is now being used against our kids. Ten thousand out of 12
column13: 000 Humvees aren't armored. I visited some of those kids with no limbs today
column14: because they didn't have the armor on those vehicles. They didn't have the right body armor.  I've met parents who've on the Internet gotten the armor to send their kids.  There is no bigger judgment for a president of the United states than how you take a nation to war. And you can't say
column15: because Saddam might have done it 10 years from now
column16: that's a reason; that's an excuse.

column2: but here's what I'll say about the $87 billion. I made a mistake in the way I talk about it. He made a mistake in invading Iraq. Which is a worse decision?  Now
column3: I voted the way I voted because I saw that he had the policy wrong and I wanted accountability. I didn't want to give a slush fund to Halliburton. I also thought the wealthiest people in America ought to pay for it
column4: ladies and gentlemen. He wants your kids to pay for it. I wanted us to pay for it
column5: since we're at war. I don't think that's a bad decision.

column1: I have made a lot of decisions
column3: like appointments to boards you never heard of
column4: and some of them big. And in a war
column5: there's a lot of -- there's a lot of tactical decisions that historians will look back and say: He shouldn't have done that. He shouldn't have made that decision. And I'll take responsibility for them. I'm human.  But on the big questions
column6: about whether or not we should have gone into Afghanistan
column7: the big question about whether we should have removed somebody in Iraq
column9: because I think they're right.  That's really what you're -- when they ask about the mistakes
column10: that's what they're talking about. They're trying to say
column11: ""Did you make a mistake going into Iraq?"" And the answer is
column12: ""Absolutely not."" It was the right decision.  The Duelfer report confirmed that decision today
column13: because what Saddam Hussein was doing was trying to get rid of sanctions so he could reconstitute a weapons program. And the biggest threat facing America is terrorists with weapons of mass destruction.  We knew he hated us. We knew he'd been -- invaded other countries. We knew he tortured his own people.  On the tax cut
column14: it's a big decision. I did the right decision. Our recession was one of the shallowest in modern history.  Now
column15: you asked what mistakes. I made some mistakes in appointing people
column16: but I'm not going to name them. I don't want to hurt their feelings on national TV.  (LAUGHTER)

column2: and I'm fully prepared to accept any mistakes that history judges to my administration
column3: because the president makes the decisions
column4: the president has to take the responsibility.

column1: I believe the president made a huge mistake
column3: not to live up to his own standard
column4: which was: build a true global coalition
column5: give the inspectors time to finish their job and go through the U.N. process to its end and go to war as a last resort. I ask each of you just to look into your hearts
column6: look into your guts. Gut-check time. Was this really going to war as a last resort?  The president rushed our nation to war without a plan to win the peace. And simple things weren't done.  That's why Senator Lugar says: incompetent in the delivery of services. That's why Senator Hagel
column7: Republican
column9: you know: beyond pitiful
column10: beyond embarrassing
column11: in the zone of dangerous.  We didn't guard 850
column12: 000 tons of ammo. That ammo is now being used against our kids. Ten thousand out of 12
column13: 000 Humvees aren't armored. I visited some of those kids with no limbs today
column14: because they didn't have the armor on those vehicles. They didn't have the right body armor.  I've met parents who've on the Internet gotten the armor to send their kids.  There is no bigger judgment for a president of the United states than how you take a nation to war. And you can't say
column15: because Saddam might have done it 10 years from now
column16: that's a reason; that's an excuse.

column2: yet he voted against the $87 billion supplemental I sent to the Congress and then issued one of the most amazing quotes in political history: ""I actually did vote for the $87 billion before I voted against it."" Saddam Hussein was a risk to our country
column3: ma'am. And he was a risk that -- and this is where we just have a difference of opinion.  The truth of that matter is
column4: if you listen carefully
column5: Saddam would still be in power if he were the president of the United States
column6: ""And the world would be a lot better off.""

column2: but here's what I'll say about the $87 billion. I made a mistake in the way I talk about it. He made a mistake in invading Iraq. Which is a worse decision?  Now
column3: I voted the way I voted because I saw that he had the policy wrong and I wanted accountability. I didn't want to give a slush fund to Halliburton. I also thought the wealthiest people in America ought to pay for it
column4: ladies and gentlemen. He wants your kids to pay for it. I wanted us to pay for it
column5: since we're at war. I don't think that's a bad decision.
