column3: 17)	" Do you want to go first?

column2: thank you.  And thank you all.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column3: 17)	" Do you want to go first?

column2: thank you.  And thank you all.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column2: thank you.  And thank you all.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column3: 17)	" Do you want to go first?

column2: thank you.  And thank you all.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column2: thank you.  And thank you all.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column3: 17)	" Do you want to go first?

column2: thank you.  And thank you all.

column3: for taking part. Thanks for your questions tonight
column4: very
column5: very much.  Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions. I respect him for that. But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.  I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation. I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation
column6: not a country
column7: not an institution.  But I know
column9: that our country is strongest when we lead the world
column10: when we lead strong alliances. And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.  We are not doing that today. We need to.  I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.  And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly
column11: getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start
column12: with new credibility
column13: with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.  In addition to that
column14: I believe we have a crisis here at home
column15: a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed
column16: health-care costs going up.  I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.  I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.  I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents. That's the test.  I believe America's best days are ahead of us. I'm an optimist
column17: but we have to make the right choices
column18: to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future. We can do this.  And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.  Thank you.

column2: thanks. Thank you all very much. It's been enjoyable.  The great contest for the presidency is about the future
column3: who can lead
column4: who can get things done.  We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession
column5: corporate scandals
column6: war.  And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.  We're on the move.  Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low
column7: don't increase the scope of the federal government
column9: legal reform
column10: a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals
column11: and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.  And abroad
column12: we're at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.  The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done.  We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists. We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.  But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.  Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow
column13: Afghanistan will be voting for a president. In Iraq
column14: we'll be having free elections
column15: and a free society will make this world more peaceful.  God bless.

column3: 2)	" Each situation is different
column4: Robin. And obviously we hope that diplomacy works before you ever use force. The hardest decision a president makes is ever to use force.  After 9/11
column5: we had to look at the world differently. After 9/11
column6: we had to recognize that when we saw a threat
column7: we must take it seriously before it comes to hurt us.  In the old days we'd see a threat
column8: and we could deal with it if we felt like it or not. But 9/11 changed it all.  I vowed to our countrymen that I would do everything I could to protect the American people. That's why we're bringing Al Qaida to justice. Seventy five percent of them have been brought to justice.  That's why I said to Afghanistan: If you harbor a terrorist
column9: you're just as guilty as the terrorist. And the Taliban is no longer in power
column10: and Al Qaida no longer has a place to plan.  And I saw a unique threat in Saddam Hussein
column11: as did my opponent
column12: because we thought he had weapons of mass destruction.  And the unique threat was that he could give weapons of mass destruction to an organization like Al Qaida
column13: and the harm they inflicted on us with airplanes would be multiplied greatly by weapons of mass destruction. And that was the serious
column14: serious threat.  So I tried diplomacy
column15: went to the United Nations. But as we learned in the same report I quoted
column16: Saddam Hussein was gaming the oil-for-food program to get rid of sanctions. He was trying to get rid of sanctions for a reason: He wanted to restart his weapons programs.  We all thought there was weapons there
column17: Robin. My opponent thought there was weapons there. That's why he called him a grave threat.  I wasn't happy when we found out there wasn't weapons
column18: and we've got an intelligence group together to figure out why.  But Saddam Hussein was a unique threat. And the world is better off without him in power.  And my opponent's plans lead me to conclude that Saddam Hussein would still be in power
column19: and the world would be more dangerous.  Thank you
column20: sir.

column2: I'm going to answer your question. I'm also going to talk -- respond to what you asked
column3: Cheryl
column4: at the same time.  The world is more dangerous today. The world is more dangerous today because the president didn't make the right judgments.  Now
column5: the president wishes that I had changed my mind. He wants you to believe that because he can't come here and tell you that he's created new jobs for America. He's lost jobs.  He can't come here and tell you that he's created health care for Americans because
column6: what
column7: we've got 5 million Americans who have lost their health care
column9: 000 of them right here in Missouri.  He can't come here and tell you that he's left no child behind because he didn't fund no child left behind.  So what does he do? He's trying to attack me. He wants you to believe that I can't be president. And he's trying to make you believe it because he wants you to think I change my mind.  Well
column10: let me tell you straight up: I've never changed my mind about Iraq. I do believe Saddam Hussein was a threat. I always believed he was a threat. Believed it in 1998 when Clinton was president. I wanted to give Clinton the power to use force if necessary.  But I would have used that force wisely
column11: I would have used that authority wisely
column12: not rushed to war without a plan to win the peace.  I would have brought our allies to our side. I would have fought to make certain our troops had everybody possible to help them win the mission.  This president rushed to war
column13: pushed our allies aside. And Iran now is more dangerous
column14: and so is North Korea
column15: with nuclear weapons. He took his eye off the ball
column16: off of Osama bin Laden.

column1: You remember the last debate? My opponent said that America must pass a global test before we used force to protect ourselves. That's the kind of mindset that says sanctions were working. That's the kind of mindset that said
column2: ""Let's keep it at the United Nations and hope things go well.""  Saddam Hussein was a threat because he could have given weapons of mass destruction to terrorist enemies. Sanctions were not working. The United Nations was not effective at removing Saddam Hussein.

column1: The goal of the sanctions was not to remove Saddam Hussein
column2: it was to remove the weapons of mass destruction. And
column3: Mr. President
column4: just yesterday the Duelfer report told you and the whole world they worked. He didn't have weapons of mass destruction
column5: Mr. President. That was the objective. And if we'd used smart diplomacy
column6: we could have saved $200 billion and an invasion of Iraq. And right now
column7: Osama bin Laden might be in jail or dead. That's the war against terror.

column3: 2)	" Each situation is different
column4: Robin. And obviously we hope that diplomacy works before you ever use force. The hardest decision a president makes is ever to use force.  After 9/11
column5: we had to look at the world differently. After 9/11
column6: we had to recognize that when we saw a threat
column7: we must take it seriously before it comes to hurt us.  In the old days we'd see a threat
column8: and we could deal with it if we felt like it or not. But 9/11 changed it all.  I vowed to our countrymen that I would do everything I could to protect the American people. That's why we're bringing Al Qaida to justice. Seventy five percent of them have been brought to justice.  That's why I said to Afghanistan: If you harbor a terrorist
column9: you're just as guilty as the terrorist. And the Taliban is no longer in power
column10: and Al Qaida no longer has a place to plan.  And I saw a unique threat in Saddam Hussein
column11: as did my opponent
column12: because we thought he had weapons of mass destruction.  And the unique threat was that he could give weapons of mass destruction to an organization like Al Qaida
column13: and the harm they inflicted on us with airplanes would be multiplied greatly by weapons of mass destruction. And that was the serious
column14: serious threat.  So I tried diplomacy
column15: went to the United Nations. But as we learned in the same report I quoted
column16: Saddam Hussein was gaming the oil-for-food program to get rid of sanctions. He was trying to get rid of sanctions for a reason: He wanted to restart his weapons programs.  We all thought there was weapons there
column17: Robin. My opponent thought there was weapons there. That's why he called him a grave threat.  I wasn't happy when we found out there wasn't weapons
column18: and we've got an intelligence group together to figure out why.  But Saddam Hussein was a unique threat. And the world is better off without him in power.  And my opponent's plans lead me to conclude that Saddam Hussein would still be in power
column19: and the world would be more dangerous.  Thank you
column20: sir.

column3: 3)	" Anthony
column4: I would not. I have laid out a different plan
column5: because the president's plan is not working. You see that every night on television. There's chaos in Iraq. King Abdullah of Jordan said just yesterday or the day before you can't hold elections in Iraq with the chaos that's going on today.  Senator Richard Lugar
column6: the Republican chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee
column7: said that the handling of the reconstruction aid in Iraq by this administration has been incompetent. Those are the Republican chairman's words.  Senator Hagel of Nebraska said that the handling of Iraq is beyond pitiful
column8: beyond embarrassing; it's in the zone of dangerous.  Those are the words of two Republicans
column9: respected
column10: both on the Foreign Relations Committee.  Now
column11: I have to tell you
column12: I would do something different. I would reach out to our allies in a way that this president hasn't. He pushed them away time and again
column13: pushed them away at the U.N.
column14: pushed them away individually.  Two weeks ago
column15: there was a meeting of the North Atlantic Council
column16: which is the political arm of NATO. They discussed the possibility of a small training unit or having a total takeover of the training in Iraq.  Did our administration push for the total training of Iraq? No. Were they silent? Yes.  Was there an effort to bring all the allies together around that? No
column17: because they've always wanted this to be an American effort.  You know
column18: they even had the Defense Department issue a memorandum saying
column19: ""Don't bother applying for assistance or for being part of the reconstruction if you weren't part of our original coalition.""  Now
column20: that's not a good way to build support and reduce the risk for our troops and make America safer.  I'm going to get the training done for our troops. I'm going to get the training of Iraqis done faster. And I'm going to get our allies back to the table.

column1: Two days ago in the Oval Office
column2: I met with the finance minister from Iraq. He came to see me. And he talked about how optimistic he was and the country was about heading toward elections. Think about it: They're going from tyranny to elections.  He talked about the reconstruction efforts that are beginning to take hold. He talked about the fact that Iraqis love to be free.  He said he was optimistic when he came here
column3: then he turned on the TV and listened to the political rhetoric and all of a sudden he was pessimistic.  Now
column4: this is guy a who
column5: along with others
column6: has taken great risk for great freedom. And we need to stand with him.  My opponent says he has a plan; it sounds familiar
column7: because it's called the Bush plan. We're going to train troops
column9: 000 trained by the end of December. We're spending about $7 billion.  He talks about a grand idea: Let's have a summit; we're going to solve the problem in Iraq by holding a summit.  And what is he going to say to those people that show up at the summit? Join me in the wrong war at the wrong time at the wrong place. Risk your troops in a war you've called a mistake.  Nobody is going to follow somebody who doesn't believe we can succeed and with somebody who says that war where we are is a mistake.  I know how these people think. I meet with them all the time. I talk to Tony Blair all the time. I talk to Silvio Berlusconi. They're not going to follow an American president who says follow me into a mistake. Our plan is working. We're going to make elections. And Iraq is going to be free
column10: and America will be better off for it.

column3: please. Ladies and gentlemen
column4: the right war was Osama bin Laden and Afghanistan. That was the right place. And the right time was Tora Bora
column5: when we had him cornered in the mountains.  Now
column6: everyone in the world knows that there were no weapons of mass destruction. That was the reason Congress gave him the authority to use force
column7: not after excuse to get rid of the regime.  Now we have to succeed. I've always said that. I have been consistent. Yes
column9: and I have a better plan to help us do it.

column2: we didn't find out he didn't have weapons until we got there
column3: and my opponent thought he had weapons and told everybody he thought he had weapons. And secondly
column4: it's a fundamental misunderstanding to say that the war on terror is only Osama bin Laden. The war on terror is to make sure that these terrorist organizations do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. That's what the war on terror is about.  Of course
column5: we're going to find Osama bin Laden. We've already 75 percent of his people. And we're on the hunt for him.  But this is a global conflict that requires firm resolve.

And what is he going to say to those people that show up at the summit? Join me in the wrong war at the wrong time at the wrong place. Risk your troops in a war you've called a mistake. column55: has taken great risk for great freedom.'

column3: 4)	" No
column4: I appreciate that. I -- listen
column5: I -- we've got a great country. I love our values. And I recognize I've made some decisions that have caused people to not understand the great values of our country. I remember when Ronald Reagan was the president; he stood on principle. Somebody called that stubborn. He stood on principle standing up to the Soviet Union
column6: and we won that conflict. Yet at the same time
column7: he was very -- we were very unpopular in Europe because of the decisions he made.  I recognize that taking Saddam Hussein out was unpopular. But I made the decision because I thought it was in the right interests of our security.  You know
column8: I've made some decisions on Israel that's unpopular. I wouldn't deal with Arafat
column9: because I felt like he had let the former president down
column10: and I don't think he's the kind of person that can lead toward a Palestinian state.  And people in Europe didn't like that decision. And that was unpopular
column11: but it was the right thing to do.  I believe Palestinians ought to have a state
column12: but I know they need leadership that's committed to a democracy and freedom
column13: leadership that would be willing to reject terrorism.  I made a decision not to join the International Criminal Court in The Hague
column14: which is where our troops could be brought to -- brought in front of a judge
column15: an unaccounted judge.  I don't think we ought to join that. That was unpopular.  And so
column16: what I'm telling you is
column17: is that sometimes in this world you make unpopular decisions because you think they're right.  We'll continue to reach out.  Listen
column18: there is 30 nations involved in Iraq
column19: some 40 nations involved in Afghanistan.  People love America. Sometimes they don't like the decisions made by America
column20: but I don't think you want a president who tries to become popular and does the wrong thing.  You don't want to join the International Criminal Court just because it's popular in certain capitals in Europe.

column2: that's a question that's been raised by a lot of people around the country. Let me address it but also talk about the weapons the president just talked about
column3: because every part of the president's answer just now promises you more of the same over the next four years.  The president stood right here in this hall four years ago
column4: and he was asked a question by somebody just like you
column5: ""Under what circumstances would you send people to war?""  And his answer was
column6: ""With a viable exit strategy and only with enough forces to get the job done.""  He didn't do that. He broke that promise. We didn't have enough forces.  General Shinseki
column7: the Army chief of staff
column8: told him he was going to need several hundred thousand. And guess what? They retired General Shinseki for telling him that.  This president hasn't listened.  I went to meet with the members of the Security Council in the week before we voted. I went to New York. I talked to all of them to find out how serious they were about really holding Saddam Hussein accountable.  I came away convinced that
column9: if we worked at it
column10: if we were ready to work and letting Hans Blix do his job and thoroughly go through the inspections
column11: that if push came to shove
column12: they'd be there with us.  But the president just arbitrarily brought the hammer down and said
column13: ""Nope. Sorry
column14: time for diplomacy is over. We're going.""  He rushed to war without a plan to win the peace.  Ladies and gentleman
column15: he gave you a speech and told you he'd plan carefully
column16: take every precaution
column17: take our allies with us. He didn't. He broke his word.

column1: I remember sitting in the White House looking at those generals
column3: ""Do you have what you need in this war? Do you have what it takes?"" I remember going down to the basement of the White House the day we committed our troops as last resort
column4: looking at Tommy Franks and the generals on the ground
column5: asking them
column6: ""Do we have the right plan with the right troop level?""  And they looked me in the eye and said
column7: ""Yes
column9: Mr. President."" Of course
column10: I listen to our generals. That's what a president does. A president sets the strategy and relies upon good military people to execute that strategy.

column1: You rely on good military people to execute the military component of the strategy
column2: but winning the peace is larger than just the military component. General Shinseki had the wisdom to say
column3: ""You're going to need several hundred thousand troops to win the peace."" The military's job is to win the war.  A president's job is to win the peace.  The president did not do what was necessary. Didn't bring in enough nation. Didn't deliver the help. Didn't close off the borders. Didn't even guard the ammo dumps. And now our kids are being killed with ammos right out of that dump.

column1: I don't think you can just rely on U.N. sanctions
column3: it is a threat
column4: it's a huge threat. And what's interesting is
column5: it's a threat that has grown while the president has been preoccupied with Iraq
column6: where there wasn't a threat.  If he'd let the inspectors do their job and go on
column7: we wouldn't have 10 times the numbers of forces in Iraq that we have in Afghanistan chasing Osama bin Laden.  Meanwhile
column8: while Iran is moving toward nuclear weapons
column9: some 37 tons of what they called yellow cake
column10: the stuff they use to make enriched uranium
column11: while they're doing that
column12: North Korea has moved from one bomb maybe
column13: maybe
column14: to four to seven bombs.  For two years
column15: the president didn't even engage with North Korea
column16: did nothing at all
column17: while it was growing more dangerous
column18: despite the warnings of former Secretary of Defense William Perry
column19: who negotiated getting television cameras and inspectors into that reactor.  We were safer before President Bush came to office. Now they have the bombs and we're less safe.  So what do we do? We've got to join with the British and the French
column20: with the Germans
column21: who've been involved
column22: in their initiative. We've got to lead the world now to crack down on proliferation as a whole.  But the president's been slow to do that
column23: even in Russia.  At his pace
column24: it's going to take 13 years to reduce and get ahold of all the loose nuclear material in the former Soviet Union. I've proposed a plan that can capture it and contain it and clean it within four years.  And the president is moving to the creation of our own bunker- busting nuclear weapon. It's very hard to get other countries to give up their weapons when you're busy developing a new one.  I'm going to lead the world in the greatest counterproliferation effort. And if we have to get tough with Iran

column1: That answer almost made me want to scowl. He keeps talking about
column2: ""Let the inspectors do their job."" It's naive and dangerous to say that. That's what the Duelfer report showed. He was deceiving the inspectors.  Secondly
column3: of course we've been involved with Iran.  I fully understand the threat. And that's why we're doing what he suggested we do: Get the Brits
column4: the Germans and the French to go make it very clear to the Iranians that if they expect to be a party to the world to give up their nuclear ambitions. We've been doing that.  Let me talk about North Korea.  It is naive and dangerous to take a policy that he suggested the other day
column5: which is to have bilateral relations with North Korea. Remember
column6: he's the person who's accusing me of not acting multilaterally. He now wants to take the six-party talks we have -- China
column7: North Korea
column9: Russia
column10: Japan and the United States -- and undermine them by having bilateral talks.  That's what President Clinton did. He had bilateral talks with the North Koreans. And guess what happened?  He didn't honor the agreement. He was enriching uranium. That is a bad policy.  Of course
column11: we're paying attention to these. It's a great question about Iran. That's why in my speech to the Congress I said: There's an ""Axis of Evil
column12: Iraq
column13: Iran and North Korea
column14: and we're paying attention to it. And we're making progress.

column16: did nothing at all
column17: while it was growing more dangerous
column18: despite the warnings of former Secretary of Defense William Perry
column19: who negotiated getting television cameras and inspectors into that reactor.  We were safer before President Bush came to office. Now they have the bombs and we're less safe.  So what do we do? We've got to join with the British and the French
column20: with the Germans
column21: who've been involved
column22: in their initiative. We've got to lead the world now to crack down on proliferation as a whole.  But the president's been slow to do that
column23: even in Russia.  At his pace
column24: it's going to take 13 years to reduce and get ahold of all the loose nuclear material in the former Soviet Union. I've proposed a plan that can capture it and contain it and clean it within four years.  And the president is moving to the creation of our own bunker- busting nuclear weapon. It's very hard to get other countries to give up their weapons when you're busy developing a new one.  I'm going to lead the world in the greatest counterproliferation effort. column1: That answer almost made me want to scowl. He keeps talking about
column2: ""Let the inspectors do their job."" It's naive and dangerous to say that. That's what the Duelfer report showed. He was deceiving the inspectors.  Secondly
column3: of course we've been involved with Iran.  I fully understand the threat. And that's why we're doing what he suggested we do: Get the Brits
column4: the Germans and the French to go make it very clear to the Iranians that if they expect to be a party to the world to give up their nuclear ambitions. We've been doing that.  Let me talk about North Korea.  It is naive and dangerous to take a policy that he suggested the other day
column5: which is to have bilateral relations with North Korea. Remember
column6: he's the person who's accusing me of not acting multilaterally. He now wants to take the six-party talks we have -- China
column7: North Korea
column9: Russia
column10: Japan and the United States -- and undermine them by having bilateral talks.  That's what President Clinton did. He had bilateral talks with the North Koreans. And guess what happened?  He didn't honor the agreement. He was enriching uranium. That is a bad policy.  Of course
column11: we're paying attention to these. It's a great question about Iran. That's why in my speech to the Congress I said: There's an ""Axis of Evil
column12: Iraq
column13: Iran and North Korea
column14: and we're paying attention to it. And we're making progress.

column3: 7)	" Thank you very much
column4: Ann. I've asked in my security briefings why that is
column5: and I can't go into all the answers
column6: et cetera
column7: but let me say this to you.  This president and his administration have told you and all of us it's not a question of when
column8: it's a question of -- excuse me -- not a question of if
column9: it's a question of when. We've been told that.  The when I can't tell you. Between the World Trade Center bombing in
column10: what was it
column11: 1993 or so
column12: and the next time was five years
column13: seven years. These people wait. They'll plan. They plot.  I agree with the president that we have to go after them and get them wherever they are. I just think I can do that far more effectively
column14: because the most important weapon in doing that is intelligence. You've got to have the best intelligence in the world.  And in order to have the best intelligence in the world to know who the terrorists are and where they are and what they're plotting
column15: you've got to have the best cooperation you've ever had in the world.  Now
column16: to go back to your question
column18: we're not getting the best cooperation in the world today. We've got a whole bunch of countries that pay a price for dealing with the United States of America now. I'm going to change that.  And I'm going to put in place a better homeland security effort.  Look
column19: 95 percent of our containers coming into this country are not inspected today. When you get on an airplane
column20: your bag is X- rayed
column21: but the cargo hold isn't X-rayed. Do you feel safer?  This president in the last debate said
column22: ""Well
column23: that would be a big tax gap if we did that.""  Ladies and gentlemen
column24: it's his tax plan. He chose a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans over getting that equipment out into the homeland as fast as possible.  We have bridges and tunnels that aren't being secured
column27: hospitals that are overcrowded with their emergency rooms.  If we had a disaster today
column28: could they handle it?  This president chose a tax cut over homeland security. Wrong choice.

column1: That's an odd thing to say
column2: since we've tripled the homeland security budget from $10 billion to $30 billion. Listen
column3: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.  My opponent's right
column4: we need good intelligence. It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.  The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense. We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home
column5: and they got to be right once. And that's the reality.  And there's a lot of good people working hard. We're doing the best we possibly can to share information. That's why the Patriot Act was important.  The Patriot Act is vital
column6: by the way. It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other. My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it. No
column7: but he's for weakening it.  I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.  First of all
column8: I don't think he can succeed in Iraq. And if Iraq were to fail
column9: it'd be a haven for terrorists
column10: and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.  I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place. I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.  I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long
column11: long war
column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column2: the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious
column3: they're deadly
column4: and they know nothing except trying to kill. I understand that. That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.  Folks
column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column2: we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes
column3: I'm worried. I'm worried. I'm worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime
column4: doing the very best they can. And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate. And the way to defeat them long-term
column5: by the way
column6: is to spread freedom.  Liberty can change habits. And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.

column3: 7)	" Thank you very much
column4: Ann. I've asked in my security briefings why that is
column5: and I can't go into all the answers
column6: et cetera
column7: but let me say this to you.  This president and his administration have told you and all of us it's not a question of when
column8: it's a question of -- excuse me -- not a question of if
column9: it's a question of when. We've been told that.  The when I can't tell you. Between the World Trade Center bombing in
column10: what was it
column11: 1993 or so
column12: and the next time was five years
column13: seven years. These people wait. They'll plan. They plot.  I agree with the president that we have to go after them and get them wherever they are. I just think I can do that far more effectively
column14: because the most important weapon in doing that is intelligence. You've got to have the best intelligence in the world.  And in order to have the best intelligence in the world to know who the terrorists are and where they are and what they're plotting
column15: you've got to have the best cooperation you've ever had in the world.  Now
column16: to go back to your question
column18: we're not getting the best cooperation in the world today. We've got a whole bunch of countries that pay a price for dealing with the United States of America now. I'm going to change that.  And I'm going to put in place a better homeland security effort.  Look
column19: 95 percent of our containers coming into this country are not inspected today. When you get on an airplane
column20: your bag is X- rayed
column21: but the cargo hold isn't X-rayed. Do you feel safer?  This president in the last debate said
column22: ""Well
column23: that would be a big tax gap if we did that.""  Ladies and gentlemen
column24: it's his tax plan. He chose a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans over getting that equipment out into the homeland as fast as possible.  We have bridges and tunnels that aren't being secured
column27: hospitals that are overcrowded with their emergency rooms.  If we had a disaster today
column28: could they handle it?  This president chose a tax cut over homeland security. Wrong choice.

column1: That's an odd thing to say
column2: since we've tripled the homeland security budget from $10 billion to $30 billion. Listen
column3: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.  My opponent's right
column4: we need good intelligence. It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.  The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense. We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home
column5: and they got to be right once. And that's the reality.  And there's a lot of good people working hard. We're doing the best we possibly can to share information. That's why the Patriot Act was important.  The Patriot Act is vital
column6: by the way. It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other. My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it. No
column7: but he's for weakening it.  I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.  First of all
column8: I don't think he can succeed in Iraq. And if Iraq were to fail
column9: it'd be a haven for terrorists
column10: and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.  I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place. I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.  I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long
column11: long war
column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column2: the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious
column3: they're deadly
column4: and they know nothing except trying to kill. I understand that. That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.  Folks
column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column2: we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes
column3: I'm worried. I'm worried. I'm worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime
column4: doing the very best they can. And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate. And the way to defeat them long-term
column5: by the way
column6: is to spread freedom.  Liberty can change habits. And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.

column4: we need good intelligence. It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.  The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense. We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home
column5: and they got to be right once. And that's the reality.  And there's a lot of good people working hard. We're doing the best we possibly can to share information. That's why the Patriot Act was important.  The Patriot Act is vital
column6: by the way. It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other. My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it. No
column7: but he's for weakening it.  I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.  First of all
column8: I don't think he can succeed in Iraq. And if Iraq were to fail
column9: it'd be a haven for terrorists
column10: and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.  I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place. I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.  I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long
column11: long war
column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column2: the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious
column3: they're deadly
column4: and they know nothing except trying to kill. I understand that. That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.  Folks
column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column2: we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes
column3: I'm worried. I'm worried. I'm worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime
column4: doing the very best they can. And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate. And the way to defeat them long-term
column5: by the way
column6: is to spread freedom.  Liberty can change habits. And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.

column3: 7)	" Thank you very much
column4: Ann. I've asked in my security briefings why that is
column5: and I can't go into all the answers
column6: et cetera
column7: but let me say this to you.  This president and his administration have told you and all of us it's not a question of when
column8: it's a question of -- excuse me -- not a question of if
column9: it's a question of when. We've been told that.  The when I can't tell you. Between the World Trade Center bombing in
column10: what was it
column11: 1993 or so
column12: and the next time was five years
column13: seven years. These people wait. They'll plan. They plot.  I agree with the president that we have to go after them and get them wherever they are. I just think I can do that far more effectively
column14: because the most important weapon in doing that is intelligence. You've got to have the best intelligence in the world.  And in order to have the best intelligence in the world to know who the terrorists are and where they are and what they're plotting
column15: you've got to have the best cooperation you've ever had in the world.  Now
column16: to go back to your question
column18: we're not getting the best cooperation in the world today. We've got a whole bunch of countries that pay a price for dealing with the United States of America now. I'm going to change that.  And I'm going to put in place a better homeland security effort.  Look
column19: 95 percent of our containers coming into this country are not inspected today. When you get on an airplane
column20: your bag is X- rayed
column21: but the cargo hold isn't X-rayed. Do you feel safer?  This president in the last debate said
column22: ""Well
column23: that would be a big tax gap if we did that.""  Ladies and gentlemen
column24: it's his tax plan. He chose a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans over getting that equipment out into the homeland as fast as possible.  We have bridges and tunnels that aren't being secured
column27: hospitals that are overcrowded with their emergency rooms.  If we had a disaster today
column28: could they handle it?  This president chose a tax cut over homeland security. Wrong choice.

column1: That's an odd thing to say
column2: since we've tripled the homeland security budget from $10 billion to $30 billion. Listen
column3: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.  My opponent's right
column4: we need good intelligence. It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.  The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense. We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home
column5: and they got to be right once. And that's the reality.  And there's a lot of good people working hard. We're doing the best we possibly can to share information. That's why the Patriot Act was important.  The Patriot Act is vital
column6: by the way. It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other. My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it. No
column7: but he's for weakening it.  I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.  First of all
column8: I don't think he can succeed in Iraq. And if Iraq were to fail
column9: it'd be a haven for terrorists
column10: and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.  I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place. I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.  I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long
column11: long war
column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column2: the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious
column3: they're deadly
column4: and they know nothing except trying to kill. I understand that. That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.  Folks
column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column2: we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes
column3: I'm worried. I'm worried. I'm worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime
column4: doing the very best they can. And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate. And the way to defeat them long-term
column5: by the way
column6: is to spread freedom.  Liberty can change habits. And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.

column3: 7)	" Thank you very much
column4: Ann. I've asked in my security briefings why that is
column5: and I can't go into all the answers
column6: et cetera
column7: but let me say this to you.  This president and his administration have told you and all of us it's not a question of when
column8: it's a question of -- excuse me -- not a question of if
column9: it's a question of when. We've been told that.  The when I can't tell you. Between the World Trade Center bombing in
column10: what was it
column11: 1993 or so
column12: and the next time was five years
column13: seven years. These people wait. They'll plan. They plot.  I agree with the president that we have to go after them and get them wherever they are. I just think I can do that far more effectively
column14: because the most important weapon in doing that is intelligence. You've got to have the best intelligence in the world.  And in order to have the best intelligence in the world to know who the terrorists are and where they are and what they're plotting
column15: you've got to have the best cooperation you've ever had in the world.  Now
column16: to go back to your question
column18: we're not getting the best cooperation in the world today. We've got a whole bunch of countries that pay a price for dealing with the United States of America now. I'm going to change that.  And I'm going to put in place a better homeland security effort.  Look
column19: 95 percent of our containers coming into this country are not inspected today. When you get on an airplane
column20: your bag is X- rayed
column21: but the cargo hold isn't X-rayed. Do you feel safer?  This president in the last debate said
column22: ""Well
column23: that would be a big tax gap if we did that.""  Ladies and gentlemen
column24: it's his tax plan. He chose a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans over getting that equipment out into the homeland as fast as possible.  We have bridges and tunnels that aren't being secured
column27: hospitals that are overcrowded with their emergency rooms.  If we had a disaster today
column28: could they handle it?  This president chose a tax cut over homeland security. Wrong choice.

column1: That's an odd thing to say
column2: since we've tripled the homeland security budget from $10 billion to $30 billion. Listen
column3: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.  My opponent's right
column4: we need good intelligence. It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.  The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense. We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home
column5: and they got to be right once. And that's the reality.  And there's a lot of good people working hard. We're doing the best we possibly can to share information. That's why the Patriot Act was important.  The Patriot Act is vital
column6: by the way. It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other. My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it. No
column7: but he's for weakening it.  I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.  First of all
column8: I don't think he can succeed in Iraq. And if Iraq were to fail
column9: it'd be a haven for terrorists
column10: and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.  I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place. I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.  I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long
column11: long war
column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column2: the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious
column3: they're deadly
column4: and they know nothing except trying to kill. I understand that. That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.  Folks
column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column2: we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes
column3: I'm worried. I'm worried. I'm worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime
column4: doing the very best they can. And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate. And the way to defeat them long-term
column5: by the way
column6: is to spread freedom.  Liberty can change habits. And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.
