column3: 7)	" Thank you very much
column4: Ann. I've asked in my security briefings why that is
column5: and I can't go into all the answers
column6: et cetera
column7: but let me say this to you.  This president and his administration have told you and all of us it's not a question of when
column8: it's a question of -- excuse me -- not a question of if
column9: it's a question of when. We've been told that.  The when I can't tell you. Between the World Trade Center bombing in
column10: what was it
column11: 1993 or so
column12: and the next time was five years
column13: seven years. These people wait. They'll plan. They plot.  I agree with the president that we have to go after them and get them wherever they are. I just think I can do that far more effectively
column14: because the most important weapon in doing that is intelligence. You've got to have the best intelligence in the world.  And in order to have the best intelligence in the world to know who the terrorists are and where they are and what they're plotting
column15: you've got to have the best cooperation you've ever had in the world.  Now
column16: to go back to your question
column18: we're not getting the best cooperation in the world today. We've got a whole bunch of countries that pay a price for dealing with the United States of America now. I'm going to change that.  And I'm going to put in place a better homeland security effort.  Look
column19: 95 percent of our containers coming into this country are not inspected today. When you get on an airplane
column20: your bag is X- rayed
column21: but the cargo hold isn't X-rayed. Do you feel safer?  This president in the last debate said
column22: ""Well
column23: that would be a big tax gap if we did that.""  Ladies and gentlemen
column24: it's his tax plan. He chose a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans over getting that equipment out into the homeland as fast as possible.  We have bridges and tunnels that aren't being secured
column27: hospitals that are overcrowded with their emergency rooms.  If we had a disaster today
column28: could they handle it?  This president chose a tax cut over homeland security. Wrong choice.

column1: That's an odd thing to say
column2: since we've tripled the homeland security budget from $10 billion to $30 billion. Listen
column3: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.  My opponent's right
column4: we need good intelligence. It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.  The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense. We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home
column5: and they got to be right once. And that's the reality.  And there's a lot of good people working hard. We're doing the best we possibly can to share information. That's why the Patriot Act was important.  The Patriot Act is vital
column6: by the way. It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other. My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it. No
column7: but he's for weakening it.  I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.  First of all
column8: I don't think he can succeed in Iraq. And if Iraq were to fail
column9: it'd be a haven for terrorists
column10: and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.  I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place. I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.  I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long
column11: long war
column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column2: the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious
column3: they're deadly
column4: and they know nothing except trying to kill. I understand that. That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.  But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.  Folks
column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column2: we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes
column3: I'm worried. I'm worried. I'm worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime
column4: doing the very best they can. And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate. And the way to defeat them long-term
column5: by the way
column6: is to spread freedom.  Liberty can change habits. And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.

I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.  This war is a long

column12: and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

column5: the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

column3: 8)	" I haven't yet. Just want to make sure they're safe. When a drug comes in from Canada
column4: I want to make sure it cures you and doesn't kill you. And that's why the FDA and that's why the surgeon general are looking very carefully to make sure it can be done in a safe way. I've got an obligation to make sure our government does everything we can to protect you.  And what my worry is is that
column5: you know
column6: it looks like it's from Canada
column7: and it might be from a third world.  And we've just got to make sure
column8: before somebody thinks they're buying a product
column9: that it works. And that's why we're doing what we're doing.  Now
column10: it may very well be here in December you'll hear me say
column11: I think there's a safe way to do it.  There are other ways to make sure drugs are cheaper. One is to speed up generic drugs to the marketplace
column12: quicker. Pharmaceuticals were using loopholes to keep brand -- brand drugs in place
column13: and generics are much less expensive than brand drugs. And we're doing just that.  Another is to pass -- to get our seniors to sign up to these drug discount cards
column14: and they're working.  Wanda Blackmore I met here from Missouri
column15: the first time she bought drugs with her drug discount card
column16: she paid $1.14
column18: for about $10 worth of drugs.  These cards make sense.  And
column19: you know
column20: in 2006 seniors are going to get prescription drug coverage for the first time in Medicare. Because I went to Washington to fix problems.  Medicare -- the issue of Medicare used to be called ""Mediscare."" People didn't want to touch it for fear of getting hurt politically.  I wanted to get something done. I think our seniors deserve a modern medical system. And in 2006
column21: our seniors will get prescription drug coverage.  Thank you for asking.

column2: you heard the president just say that he thought he might try to be for it. Four years ago
column3: right here in this forum
column4: he was asked the same question: Can't people be able to import drugs from Canada? You know what he said? ""I think that makes sense. I think that's a good idea"" -- four years ago.  Now
column5: the president said
column6: ""I'm not blocking that."" Ladies and gentlemen
column7: the president just didn't level with you right now again.  He did block it
column8: because we passed it in the United States Senate. We sent it over to the House
column9: that you could import drugs. We took care of the safety issues.  We're not talking about third-world drugs. We're talking about drugs made right here in the United States of America that have American brand names on them and American bottles. And we're asking to be able to allow you to get them.  The president blocked it. The president also took Medicare
column10: which belongs to you. And he could have lowered the cost of Medicare and lowered your taxes and lowered the costs to seniors.  You know what he did? He made it illegal
column11: illegal for Medicare to do what the V.A. does
column12: which is bulk purchase drugs so that you can lower the price and get them out to you lower.  He put $139 billion of windfall profit into the pockets of the drug companies right out of your pockets. That's the difference between us. The president sides with the power companies
column13: the oil companies
column14: the drug companies. And I'm fighting to let you get those drugs from Canada
column15: and I'm fighting to let Medicare survive.  I'm fighting for the middle class. That is the difference.

column2: they're coming. I want to remind you that it wasn't just my administration that made the decision on safety. President Clinton did the same thing
column3: because we have an obligation to protect you. Now
column4: he talks about Medicare. He's been in the United States Senate 20 years. Show me one accomplishment toward Medicare that he accomplished.  I've been in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: three and a half years and led the Congress to reform Medicare so our seniors have got a modern health care system. That's what leadership is all about.

column3: in 1997 we fixed Medicare
column4: and I was one of the people involved in it. We not only fixed Medicare and took it way out into the future
column5: we did something that you don't know how to do: We balanced the budget. And we paid down the debt of our nation for two years in a row
column6: and we created 23 million new jobs at the same time.  And it's the president's fiscal policies that have driven up the biggest deficits in American history. He's added more debt to the debt of the United States in four years than all the way from George Washington to Ronald Reagan put together. Go figure.

column1: Very easily. John Edwards is the author of the Patients' Bill of Rights. He wanted to give people rights. John Edwards and I support tort reform. We both believe that
column3: too. And I believe that we will be able to get a fix that has alluded everybody else because we know how to do it. It's in my health-care proposal. Go to johnkerry.com. You can pull it off of the Internet. And you'll find a tort reform plan.  Now
column4: ladies and gentlemen
column5: important to understand
column6: the president and his friends try to make a big deal out of it. Is it a problem? Yes
column7: it's a problem. Do we need to fix it
column8: particularly for OGBYNs (sic) and for brain surgeons and others? Yes.  But it's less than 1 percent of the total cost of health care.  Your premiums are going up. You've gone up
column9: in Missouri
column10: about $3
column11: 500. You've gone up 64 percent. You've seen co-pays go up
column12: deductibles go up. Everything's gone up.  Five million people have lost their health insurance under this president. He's done nothing about it.  I have a plan. I have a plan to lower the cost of health care for you. I have a plan to cover all children. I have a plan to let you buy into the same health care senators and congressmen give themselves.  I have a plan that's going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early.  And I have a plan that will take the catastrophic cases out of the system
column13: off your backs
column14: pay for it out of a federal fund
column15: which lowers the premiums for everybody in America
column16: makes American business more competitive and makes health care more affordable.  Now
column18: but I have to ask you to do one thing: Join me in rolling back the president's unaffordable tax cut for people earning more than $200
column19: 000 a year. That's all.  Ninety-eight percent of America
column20: I'm giving you a tax cut and I'm giving you health care.

column1: Let me see where to start here. First
column2: the National Journal named Senator Kennedy the most liberal senator of all. And that's saying something in that bunch. You might say that took a lot of hard work.  The reason I bring that up is because he's proposed $2.2 trillion in new spending
column3: and he says he going to tax the rich to close the tax gap.  He can't. He's going to tax everybody here to fund his programs. That's just reality.  And what are his health programs? First
column4: he says he's for medical liability reform
column5: particularly for OB/GYNs. There's a bill on the floor of the United States Senate that he could have showed up and voted for if he's so much for it.  Secondly
column6: he says that medical liability costs only cause a 1 percent increase. That shows a lack of understanding. Doctors practice defensive medicine because of all the frivolous lawsuits that cost our government $28 billion a year.  And finally
column7: he said he's going to have a novel health care plan. You know what it is? The federal government is going to run it.  It's the largest increase in federal government health care ever. And it fits with his philosophy. That's why I told you about the award he won from the National Journal.  That's what liberals do. They create government-sponsored health care. Maybe you think that makes sense. I don't.  Government-sponsored health care would lead to rationing. It would ruin the quality of health care in America.

column4: Charlie

column6: ""compassionate conservative

column9: cutting 365
column10: 000 kids from health care
column11: running up the biggest deficits in American history.  Mr. President
column12: you're batting 0 for 2.  I mean

column1: Let me see where to start here. First
column2: the National Journal named Senator Kennedy the most liberal senator of all. And that's saying something in that bunch. You might say that took a lot of hard work.  The reason I bring that up is because he's proposed $2.2 trillion in new spending
column3: and he says he going to tax the rich to close the tax gap.  He can't. He's going to tax everybody here to fund his programs. That's just reality.  And what are his health programs? First
column4: he says he's for medical liability reform
column5: particularly for OB/GYNs. There's a bill on the floor of the United States Senate that he could have showed up and voted for if he's so much for it.  Secondly
column6: he says that medical liability costs only cause a 1 percent increase. That shows a lack of understanding. Doctors practice defensive medicine because of all the frivolous lawsuits that cost our government $28 billion a year.  And finally
column7: he said he's going to have a novel health care plan. You know what it is? The federal government is going to run it.  It's the largest increase in federal government health care ever. And it fits with his philosophy. That's why I told you about the award he won from the National Journal.  That's what liberals do. They create government-sponsored health care. Maybe you think that makes sense. I don't.  Government-sponsored health care would lead to rationing. It would ruin the quality of health care in America.

column3: 9)	" Right
column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column1: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover. You have choice. Choose your doctor
column2: choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.  In fact
column3: it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it
column4: you don't have to. If you like your high premiums
column5: you keep them. That's the way we leave it.  Now with respect to the deficit
column6: the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus
column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.  Franklin Roosevelt
column9: others
column10: knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.  One percent of America
column11: the highest one percent of income earners in America
column12: got $89 billion of tax cut last year. One percent of America got more than the 80 percent of America that earned from $100
column13: 000 down.  The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.  I want to put money in your pocket. I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200
column14: 000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

column2: look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend. But let me talk back about where we've been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.  It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history
column3: which foretold a recession.  Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember
column4: we ran up the child credit by $1
column6: we reduced the marriage penalty
column7: we created a 10 percent bracket
column8: everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.

column3: the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million
column4: ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country. He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America
column5: including a $254 million refund check to Enron.  Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

column1: Absolutely. Yes. Right into the camera. Yes. I am not going to raise taxes. I have a tax cut. And here's my tax cut.  I raise the child-care credit by $1
column2: 000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.  I have a $4
column3: 000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents -- and kids
column4: if they're earning for themselves -- to be able to pay for college.  And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.  Every part of my program I've shown how I'm going to pay for it.  And I've gotten good people
column5: like former Secretary of the Treasury Bob Rubin
column6: for instance
column7: who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy
column8: to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.  I've even scaled back some of my favorite programs already
column9: like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program
column10: because the president's deficit keeps growing and I've said as a pledge
column11: ""I'm going to cut the deficit in half in four years.""  Now
column12: I'm going to restore what we did in the 1990s
column13: ladies and gentlemen: pay as you go. We're going to do it like you do it. The president broke the pay-as-you-go rule.  Somebody here asked the question about
column14: ""Why haven't you vetoed something?"" It's a good question. If you care about it
column15: why don't you veto it?  I think John McCain called the energy bill the ""No Lobbyist Left Behind"" bill.  I mean
column16: you've got to stand up and fight somewhere
column17: folks.  I'm pledging I will not raise taxes; I'm giving a tax cut to the people earning less than $200
column18: 000 a year.  Now
column19: for the people earning more than $200
column20: 000 a year
column21: you're going to see a rollback to the level we were at with Bill Clinton
column22: when people made a lot of money.  And looking around here
column23: at this group here
column24: I suspect there are only three people here who are going to be affected: the president
column27: Charlie
column28: I'm sorry
column29: you too.  (LAUGHTER)

column1: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He's just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate
column2: he voted to break the caps -- the spending caps -- over 200 times. And here he says he's going to be a fiscal conservative
column3: all of a sudden. It's just not credible. You cannot believe it.  And of course he's going to raise your taxes. You see
column4: he's proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending. And you say: Well
column5: how are you going to pay for it? He says
column6: well
column7: he's going to raise the taxes on the rich -- that's what he said -- the top two brackets. That raises
column8: he says $800 billion; we say $600 billion.  We've got battling green eye shades.  Somewhere in between those numbers -- and so there's a difference
column9: what he's promised and what he can raise.  Now
column10: either he's going to break all these wonderful promises he's told you about or he's going to raise taxes. And I suspect
column11: given his record
column12: he's going to raise taxes.  Is my time up yet?

column1: Good. You looked at me like my clock was up. I think that the way to grow this economy is to keep taxes low
column3: is to have litigation reform. As I told you
column4: we've just got a report that said over the past 13 months
column5: we've created 1.9 million new jobs. Were growing.  And so the fundamental question of this campaign is: Who's going to keep the economy growing so people can work? That's the fundamental question.

column3: the president's figures of $2.2 trillion just aren't accurate. Those are the fuzzy math figures put together by some group that works for the campaign. That's not the number. Number two
column4: John McCain and I have a proposal
column5: jointly
column6: for a commission that closes corporate giveaway loopholes. We've got $40 billion going to Bermuda. We've got all kinds of giveaways. We ought to be shutting those down.  And third
column7: credible: Ladies and gentlemen
column9: I was one of the first Democrats to move to balance the budget. I voted for the balanced budget in '93 and '97. We did it. We did it. And I was there.

column3: he's got a record. It's been there for 20 years. You can run
column4: but you can't hide. He voted 98 times to raise taxes. I mean
column5: these aren't make-up figures. And so people are going to have to look at the record. Look at the record of the man running for the president.  They don't name him the most liberal in the United States Senate because he hasn't shown up to many meetings. They named him because of his votes. And it's reality.  It's just not credible to say he's going to keep taxes down and balance budgets.

column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column1: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover. You have choice. Choose your doctor
column2: choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.  In fact
column3: it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it
column4: you don't have to. If you like your high premiums
column5: you keep them. That's the way we leave it.  Now with respect to the deficit
column6: the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus
column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.  Franklin Roosevelt
column9: others
column10: knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.  One percent of America
column11: the highest one percent of income earners in America

column13: 000 down.  The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.  I want to put money in your pocket. I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200
column14: 000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

column2: look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend. But let me talk back about where we've been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.  It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history
column3: which foretold a recession.  Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember
column4: we ran up the child credit by $1
column6: we reduced the marriage penalty
column7: we created a 10 percent bracket
column8: everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.

column3: the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million
column4: ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country. He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America
column5: including a $254 million refund check to Enron.  Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

column1: Absolutely. Yes. Right into the camera. Yes. I am not going to raise taxes. I have a tax cut. And here's my tax cut.  I raise the child-care credit by $1
column2: 000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.  I have a $4
column3: 000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents -- and kids
column4: if they're earning for themselves -- to be able to pay for college.  And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.  Every part of my program I've shown how I'm going to pay for it.  And I've gotten good people

column6: for instance
column7: who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy
column8: to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.  I've even scaled back some of my favorite programs already
column9: like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program
column10: because the president's deficit keeps growing and I've said as a pledge

column1: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He's just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate
column2: he voted to break the caps -- the spending caps -- over 200 times. And here he says he's going to be a fiscal conservative
column3: all of a sudden. It's just not credible. You cannot believe it.  And of course he's going to raise your taxes. You see
column4: he's proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending. And you say: Well
column5: how are you going to pay for it? He says
column6: well
column7: he's going to raise the taxes on the rich -- that's what he said -- the top two brackets. That raises

column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column1: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover. You have choice. Choose your doctor
column2: choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.  In fact
column3: it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it
column4: you don't have to. If you like your high premiums
column5: you keep them. That's the way we leave it.  Now with respect to the deficit
column6: the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus
column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.  Franklin Roosevelt
column9: others
column10: knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.  One percent of America
column11: the highest one percent of income earners in America
column12: got $89 billion of tax cut last year. One percent of America got more than the 80 percent of America that earned from $100
column13: 000 down.  The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.  I want to put money in your pocket. I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200
column14: 000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

column2: look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend. But let me talk back about where we've been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.  It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history
column3: which foretold a recession.  Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember
column4: we ran up the child credit by $1
column6: we reduced the marriage penalty
column7: we created a 10 percent bracket
column8: everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.

column3: the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million
column4: ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country. He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America
column5: including a $254 million refund check to Enron.  Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

column1: Absolutely. Yes. Right into the camera. Yes. I am not going to raise taxes. I have a tax cut. And here's my tax cut.  I raise the child-care credit by $1
column2: 000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.  I have a $4
column3: 000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents -- and kids
column4: if they're earning for themselves -- to be able to pay for college.  And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.  Every part of my program I've shown how I'm going to pay for it.  And I've gotten good people
column5: like former Secretary of the Treasury Bob Rubin
column6: for instance
column7: who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy
column8: to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.  I've even scaled back some of my favorite programs already
column9: like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program
column10: because the president's deficit keeps growing and I've said as a pledge

column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column1: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover. You have choice. Choose your doctor
column2: choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.  In fact
column3: it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it
column4: you don't have to. If you like your high premiums
column5: you keep them. That's the way we leave it.  Now with respect to the deficit
column6: the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus
column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.  Franklin Roosevelt
column9: others
column10: knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.  One percent of America
column11: the highest one percent of income earners in America
column12: got $89 billion of tax cut last year. One percent of America got more than the 80 percent of America that earned from $100
column13: 000 down.  The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.  I want to put money in your pocket. I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200
column14: 000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

column2: look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend. But let me talk back about where we've been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.  It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history
column3: which foretold a recession.  Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember
column4: we ran up the child credit by $1
column6: we reduced the marriage penalty
column7: we created a 10 percent bracket
column8: everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.

column3: the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million
column4: ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country. He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America
column5: including a $254 million refund check to Enron.  Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

column1: Absolutely. Yes. Right into the camera. Yes. I am not going to raise taxes. I have a tax cut. And here's my tax cut.  I raise the child-care credit by $1
column2: 000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.  I have a $4
column3: 000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents -- and kids
column4: if they're earning for themselves -- to be able to pay for college.  And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.  Every part of my program I've shown how I'm going to pay for it.  And I've gotten good people
column5: like former Secretary of the Treasury Bob Rubin
column6: for instance
column7: who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy
column8: to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.  I've even scaled back some of my favorite programs already
column9: like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program
column10: because the president's deficit keeps growing and I've said as a pledge
column11: ""I'm going to cut the deficit in half in four years.""  Now
column12: I'm going to restore what we did in the 1990s
column13: ladies and gentlemen: pay as you go. We're going to do it like you do it. The president broke the pay-as-you-go rule.  Somebody here asked the question about
column14: ""Why haven't you vetoed something?"" It's a good question. If you care about it
column15: why don't you veto it?  I think John McCain called the energy bill the ""No Lobbyist Left Behind"" bill.  I mean
column16: you've got to stand up and fight somewhere
column17: folks.  I'm pledging I will not raise taxes; I'm giving a tax cut to the people earning less than $200
column18: 000 a year.  Now
column19: for the people earning more than $200
column20: 000 a year
column21: you're going to see a rollback to the level we were at with Bill Clinton
column22: when people made a lot of money.  And looking around here
column23: at this group here
column24: I suspect there are only three people here who are going to be affected: the president
column27: Charlie
column28: I'm sorry
column29: you too.  (LAUGHTER)

column1: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He's just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate
column2: he voted to break the caps -- the spending caps -- over 200 times. And here he says he's going to be a fiscal conservative
column3: all of a sudden. It's just not credible. You cannot believe it.  And of course he's going to raise your taxes. You see
column4: he's proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending. And you say: Well
column5: how are you going to pay for it? He says
column6: well
column7: he's going to raise the taxes on the rich -- that's what he said -- the top two brackets. That raises
column8: he says $800 billion; we say $600 billion.  We've got battling green eye shades.  Somewhere in between those numbers -- and so there's a difference
column9: what he's promised and what he can raise.  Now
column10: either he's going to break all these wonderful promises he's told you about or he's going to raise taxes. And I suspect
column11: given his record
column12: he's going to raise taxes.  Is my time up yet?

column1: Good. You looked at me like my clock was up. I think that the way to grow this economy is to keep taxes low
column3: is to have litigation reform. As I told you
column4: we've just got a report that said over the past 13 months
column5: we've created 1.9 million new jobs. Were growing.  And so the fundamental question of this campaign is: Who's going to keep the economy growing so people can work? That's the fundamental question.

column3: the president's figures of $2.2 trillion just aren't accurate. Those are the fuzzy math figures put together by some group that works for the campaign. That's not the number. Number two
column4: John McCain and I have a proposal
column5: jointly
column6: for a commission that closes corporate giveaway loopholes. We've got $40 billion going to Bermuda. We've got all kinds of giveaways. We ought to be shutting those down.  And third
column7: credible: Ladies and gentlemen
column9: I was one of the first Democrats to move to balance the budget. I voted for the balanced budget in '93 and '97. We did it. We did it. And I was there.

column3: he's got a record. It's been there for 20 years. You can run
column4: but you can't hide. He voted 98 times to raise taxes. I mean
column5: these aren't make-up figures. And so people are going to have to look at the record. Look at the record of the man running for the president.  They don't name him the most liberal in the United States Senate because he hasn't shown up to many meetings. They named him because of his votes. And it's reality.  It's just not credible to say he's going to keep taxes down and balance budgets.

column3: 9)	" Right
column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column1: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover. You have choice. Choose your doctor
column2: choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.  In fact
column3: it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it
column4: you don't have to. If you like your high premiums
column5: you keep them. That's the way we leave it.  Now with respect to the deficit
column6: the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus
column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.  Franklin Roosevelt
column9: others
column10: knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.  One percent of America
column11: the highest one percent of income earners in America
column12: got $89 billion of tax cut last year. One percent of America got more than the 80 percent of America that earned from $100
column13: 000 down.  The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.  I want to put money in your pocket. I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200
column14: 000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

column2: look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend. But let me talk back about where we've been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.  It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history
column3: which foretold a recession.  Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember
column4: we ran up the child credit by $1
column6: we reduced the marriage penalty
column7: we created a 10 percent bracket
column8: everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.

column3: the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million
column4: ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country. He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America
column5: including a $254 million refund check to Enron.  Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

column1: Absolutely. Yes. Right into the camera. Yes. I am not going to raise taxes. I have a tax cut. And here's my tax cut.  I raise the child-care credit by $1
column2: 000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.  I have a $4
column3: 000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents -- and kids
column4: if they're earning for themselves -- to be able to pay for college.  And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.  Every part of my program I've shown how I'm going to pay for it.  And I've gotten good people
column5: like former Secretary of the Treasury Bob Rubin
column6: for instance
column7: who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy
column8: to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.  I've even scaled back some of my favorite programs already
column9: like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program
column10: because the president's deficit keeps growing and I've said as a pledge
column11: ""I'm going to cut the deficit in half in four years.""  Now
column12: I'm going to restore what we did in the 1990s
column13: ladies and gentlemen: pay as you go. We're going to do it like you do it. The president broke the pay-as-you-go rule.  Somebody here asked the question about
column14: ""Why haven't you vetoed something?"" It's a good question. If you care about it
column15: why don't you veto it?  I think John McCain called the energy bill the ""No Lobbyist Left Behind"" bill.  I mean
column16: you've got to stand up and fight somewhere
column17: folks.  I'm pledging I will not raise taxes; I'm giving a tax cut to the people earning less than $200
column18: 000 a year.  Now
column19: for the people earning more than $200
column20: 000 a year
column21: you're going to see a rollback to the level we were at with Bill Clinton
column22: when people made a lot of money.  And looking around here
column23: at this group here
column24: I suspect there are only three people here who are going to be affected: the president
column27: Charlie
column28: I'm sorry
column29: you too.  (LAUGHTER)

column1: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He's just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate
column2: he voted to break the caps -- the spending caps -- over 200 times. And here he says he's going to be a fiscal conservative
column3: all of a sudden. It's just not credible. You cannot believe it.  And of course he's going to raise your taxes. You see
column4: he's proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending. And you say: Well
column5: how are you going to pay for it? He says
column6: well
column7: he's going to raise the taxes on the rich -- that's what he said -- the top two brackets. That raises
column8: he says $800 billion; we say $600 billion.  We've got battling green eye shades.  Somewhere in between those numbers -- and so there's a difference
column9: what he's promised and what he can raise.  Now
column10: either he's going to break all these wonderful promises he's told you about or he's going to raise taxes. And I suspect
column11: given his record
column12: he's going to raise taxes.  Is my time up yet?

column1: Good. You looked at me like my clock was up. I think that the way to grow this economy is to keep taxes low
column3: is to have litigation reform. As I told you
column4: we've just got a report that said over the past 13 months
column5: we've created 1.9 million new jobs. Were growing.  And so the fundamental question of this campaign is: Who's going to keep the economy growing so people can work? That's the fundamental question.

column3: the president's figures of $2.2 trillion just aren't accurate. Those are the fuzzy math figures put together by some group that works for the campaign. That's not the number. Number two
column4: John McCain and I have a proposal
column5: jointly
column6: for a commission that closes corporate giveaway loopholes. We've got $40 billion going to Bermuda. We've got all kinds of giveaways. We ought to be shutting those down.  And third
column7: credible: Ladies and gentlemen
column9: I was one of the first Democrats to move to balance the budget. I voted for the balanced budget in '93 and '97. We did it. We did it. And I was there.

column3: he's got a record. It's been there for 20 years. You can run
column4: but you can't hide. He voted 98 times to raise taxes. I mean
column5: these aren't make-up figures. And so people are going to have to look at the record. Look at the record of the man running for the president.  They don't name him the most liberal in the United States Senate because he hasn't shown up to many meetings. They named him because of his votes. And it's reality.  It's just not credible to say he's going to keep taxes down and balance budgets.

column1: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He's just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate, he voted to break the caps -- the spending caps -- over 200 times. And here he says he's going to be a fiscal conservative, all of a sudden. It's just not credible. You cannot believe it.  And of course he's going to raise your taxes. column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column1: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover. You have choice. Choose your doctor
column2: choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.  In fact
column3: it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it
column4: you don't have to. If you like your high premiums
column5: you keep them. That's the way we leave it.  Now with respect to the deficit
column6: the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus
column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.  He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.  Franklin Roosevelt
column9: others
column10: knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.  One percent of America
column11: the highest one percent of income earners in America

column13: 000 down.  The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.  I want to put money in your pocket. I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200
column14: 000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

column2: look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend. But let me talk back about where we've been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.  It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history
column3: which foretold a recession.  Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember

column6: we reduced the marriage penalty
column7: we created a 10 percent bracket
column8: everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.

column3: the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million
column4: ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country. He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America
column5: including a $254 million refund check to Enron.  Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

column1: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He's just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate

column9: what he's promised and what he can raise.  Now

column3: he's got a record. It's been there for 20 years. You can run

They don't name him the most liberal in the United States Senate because he hasn't shown up to many meetings. They named him because of his votes. And it's reality.  It's just not credible to say he's going to keep taxes down and balance budgets.

column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.  I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.  And plus
column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
column11: it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow
column12: and jobs are added.  We found out today that over the past 13 months
column13: we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.  I proposed a plan
column14: detailed budget
column15: that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.  And you're right
column16: I haven't vetoed any spending bills
column18: non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it's less than 1 percent
column19: because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.  Like you
column20: I'm concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way. And I'm not going to run up taxes
column21: which will cost this economy jobs.  Thank you for your question.

column7: ladies and gentlemen. That's where he was when he came into office.  We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. column4: thank you for that. We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office
column5: and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.  Secondly
column6: we're at war. And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war
column7: more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We've got to pay our troops more. We have. We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security. column8: we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief
column9: so that they get out of the recession.  I think if you raise taxes during a recession
column10: you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times
